div.head: Act. Prim.
div.l: A Cuckold? why now it is a common name,
As the shee-Gossips are that giue it vs.
Why doth it not deriue, and spread it selfe.
To all the generations we produce?
Why should not euery child of mine be call'd
Cuckold, as well as Vaster, Woman, woman
Thou sad vndoer of the fairest building,
That euer earth bragg'd to be pauement to.
Man, Man; the pride of heauens creation,
Abstract of Nature, that in his small volume
Containes the whole worlds Text, and heauens impression:
His Makers Image, Angels mate, Earths great wonder,
Made to guide all, by woman is brought vnder.
That harmonie, faire Nature made to stand,
Is forced out of tune by womans hand.
A woman hath deform'd me. See, I looke
Like any beast has hornes: an Asse may boast
Himselfe a horne-lesse Gentleman before me.
Yet let not clouds of passion choke my reason.
Why? what's a Cuckold? let's see: define him:
div.p:
It is a man, whose wife playes the whore. Zilid, what's that to him? It is all one, as if a proper Gentleman should ride on a halting Iade; or a good Musician play on a broken fiddle. Oh but t'will be sayd: Woman could not be so light a shippe, if her husband could well ballast her. It is his insufficiencie. A poxe it is.
Had she Hercules to her husband, shee would enter the listes with some crinkle-hamm'd tilting Courtier. Well then,
div.l: I see no reason, that a womans euill,
Should thus transforme man to a horned deuill,
No: 'twas Acteons lusts, and not his wife,
That so bestagg'd him. Hence sprouts al my shame.
Fuller of truth then age, this rule hath beene:
"Nothing deformes a man, but his owne sinne.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir, my mother prayes—

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: No more of her. Her prayers.
Are putrid sacrifices: like foule ayres,
Too thicke to mount vp to yon glorious feeling.
"When blacke hands are rear'd vp, heauen has no feeling.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: She is your wife, my mother, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: What then Sir?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Nothing, but that you wrong her, ô my conscience.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Oh tis a braue Puritan-world, when boyes talke of conscience! Conscience must lye at the stake, when they play but at blow-point. Sirrah, as you loue your Conscience, hate a wife. Zlid, if I thought thou wouldst marry, I would vnblesse thee, as I haue disinherited thee already: Get bastards, as I would ha' got thee. A woman may serue to lye withal: none good enough to marry.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Oh were you not my father, I would let
This passion out of your impostum'd heart—
Why should not I forget, that your bloud moues
In any veines of mine; when you forgoe
The reason of a father, husband, man?
And sticke degeneration on your name?
If I sayle ill, know your example steer'd
My voyage and my vessell. Fathers are more
Then priuate men: their liues are the set copies.
Their children write by; and should there giue
Their imitation patternes how to liue.
Hell's a sad place, they say:— Oh, Ile dare neuer
To follow my owne father leading thither.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Sirra, call your mother. This boy's a Puritan.
I that had nere lou'd my selfe to be thought good,
Am highly pleasd to see it in my blood.
From whom deriues this sprigge such fruitfull iuyce;
The father being bad, the mother worse.
Sure, he did sucke this goodnesse from his Nurse.
Poore boy, my riot has vndone thee: poore
Thou'rt made by me, I by a wife turnd whore.
My state is morgag'd to the vsurous hand
Of Gripe: my goods are wasted: all my hopes life
Breathes thus: hauing sold all, Ile sell my wife.
sp.p: Y'are welcome, Loosenesse.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Loosenesse Sir? Oh hell!
She is my mother; pray you, vse her well.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Be gone.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I cannot Sir.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Good sonne, a way.
A father giues command.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I must obay.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Make much of you? I will, I will. Neuer man made more of his wife, when he sold her to her smocke. Ile sell thy flesh too Gypsey.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Deare husband, I am yet cleare; Oh do not you
Force me to sinne, Ile be for ouer true.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: True? true to the brothell, to the spittle, to the graue.
Thou art deaths agent: a whore is one of his Beadles.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Heauen pardon your blacke slanders.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Come, I'm poore.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Who made you?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Thou, my content, turn'd whore.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ile worke, or beg for you.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: No, thou hast wrought
Too much already. Here, here's thy worke.
Wilt thou doe one thing?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Then sweare.
And keepe thy oath. Ile trauell to the warres,
And turne thee vp, as some Captaines wont; and trie,
If thou canst liue by thy old trade, or die.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Will you forsake me then?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Yes, and am iust.
Since thou forsook'st me, and thine innocence,
Be thy reward proportion'd I must hence.
Whiles thou wast good, to thee I had free desire.
Now thou art prou'd a whore receaue thy hire.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Take place, thou tyrant will. Thicke woes here houer.
My state is lower then fate can recouer.
My obedience waits your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Hoh, within there.
Aunt Marre-maid I haue brought you the girle
I promisd. Is the mony ready?

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: By that little honesty I haue to sweare by; a handsome wench. I must pay fiftie pound for her: but if shee were as yong, as faire, I would get fiue hundred pound by her within this moneth.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Aunt, pray' vse her well: she's my owne sister.

Be petulant you whore, sprightly frollick— as a Dutch Tanikin.— or— This woman is a Bawd, a very Bawd; you like her the better for that. Come, skippe about, quicke siluer: Dance like a Curtesan, or Ile fiddle ye. You ha' more trickes in priuate, then a Fencer can teach a Lord, or the diuell a Fencer. Life, doe you pule? I must haue fiftie pound for you: Doe y' heare? Let your heeles caper, and your tongue grow wanton, or by these horns Ile gore you— Aunt, shee's somewhat sicke of that rare disease, cald Modesty. But in priuate she's more insatiate then a Puritan.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: How old are you, faire sister?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Not sixteene.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: About some sixe and fortie.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Oh you Witch— Aunt, she lies eight and twentie, at least
sp.l: Harke ye sister,—
Please this old Hagge, make her beleeue y'are right,
And answerable to her Stygian spels:
Or I will beare thee to an Armie, and there
Ha' thy sod flesh sold, lent; and prostituted,
And my selfe Cuckolded fortie times a day.
Leaue this forc'd sobernesse— Aunt, will you heare her speake?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I can skippe lighter then the wanton Doe,
And ierke it through the Dale,
I cannot hold, neither my tongue, nor heeles,
(Nor nailes from scratching out a Leachers eyes)
Sure, I am composd most of the nimbler elements:
But little water in me, farre lesse earth, some aire,
To keepe me humid, mutable, and tender,
And apt for convolution: but their mixture
Is scarce discernible, th' are so dispers'd.
For my predominant qualitie is all fire,
Pure, radiant, subtle fire.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: I haue oft seene a couple of light heeles
Carry a sober head: a womans tongue
Reade lectures of ciuilitie; her face
A printed booke, each dimple a sweet line,
That doth to good the Readers eye incline,
Neuer till now a body forc'd to doe,
What the poore mind loaths to consent vnto.
She danceth weeping, laughes and sighes in paine.
So I haue seene( me thinkes) Sun-shine in raine.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Enough, I long to imploy her. Cousin, here's the mony. She's mine. What's your name?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Florence.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Florence. I like the name well.
Its a good lucky name to make a whore on. You'l stay with me, Florence.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Till you are weary of me. Ile but take leaue of my brother, and follow you.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: What with me?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Am I not worthy of one kisse?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: There— now be gone.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Be gone? Death could not speake a word more fatall.
Yet one more— so now farewell—
Vniust— vnkind— my woe-diuining heart.
By this we first embrac'd, by this we part.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: I am a villaine, but she makes me weepe.
Why doe I thinke she's false? I neuer saw't.
Tut, all bels ring that tune. It is too true.
I told her that this fiftie pound should carry me to the warres;
But I haue a battle to fight ere I goe.
Old Gripe that has the morgage of my lands,
Lies sicke of the Goute, and seldome stirres abroad.
Some of that race Ile kill, or leaue my owne life
In pawne I would haue done 't. I ha' chalenged
Beniamin Gripe the sonne, whom the world cals
The Honest Lawyer. He comes.
sp.p: Y'are the sonne of a villaine.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: If I were, I could not helpe it.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Thy selfe's a villaine.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Its a ranke lie.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Lie? Thou exasperatst
One mad already, that would haue hazard heauen
To make this earth drunke with thy bloud.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Its deare, so bought. Twil not redeeme your soule.
Say, with deepe sluces, all these liuely springs,
That runne through the soft channels of my veines,
Should be exhaust by thee, or thine by me,
And burning malice should be quencht in bloud:
He that speeds best, wins what he should abhorre,
And glories to be curst a conqueror.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Let Sophisters alone with these distinctions.
Our moderators are our swords: the question,
That cals vs forth, as warlike disputants
Beyond decision of the gowne-furr'd peace.
Draw then thy argument, and let's talke indeed.
We cannot reason soundly, till we bleed.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Let's thinke the tearmes, on which we venture bloud.
Th'ffects are waighty, let the cause be good.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Thy father hath vndone me, and mine issue.
The law affords no succour: what remaines,
But onely to let him bleed through thy vaines?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: How haue I wrongd thee?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Aske no more. The State
Of our strife is, thou art his Sonne, I hate.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: No helpe? let fury arbitrate the rest.
This passion must but center in one brest.
Yet let's embrace, and pardon; and euen loue
In hate. O suffer not the dying blood
To preiudice the sad suruiuours good.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: What vnexpected clangor frights the peace
Of my delighted solitary walkes?
What sonnes of mischiefe in their fury tread
These vnfrequented pathes?— stay— hold.
My sonnes, heare age but speake; wisedome is old.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Peace, Dotard.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: On my knees, which doubling age
Hath scarce left able to support my corps:
By the remaining teares of fortie yeares
Spent in this penitentiall order: the last drops,
The drying hand of age hath left to dew
This witherd garden: I implore— beseech.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Father, you speake to rocks, or the surd waues.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: Then on this innocent bosome turn your swords,
And ease a weake soule of her tedious portage,
Some houre before her time. O do not flie me.
Let the few drops of my slow-pacing blood,
That stands in my cold channels, expiate yours.
Oh let a falling trunke redeeme two plants.
No remedie? let me exclaime for helpe.
sp.p: (The diuell part you:) if I should now ha' paid for my charitie— well: twas this Church-coate that sau'd me.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Oh thou hast slaine me: hold thy conquering hand.
Heauens, you are too iust pay-masters. Thy sword,
With a fate-sign'd direction, hath cut short
My hoped fortunes in a longer breath.
But I forgiue thee. Flie— stay.
I haue two Orphans in this houre depriu'd
Of a bad Parent. For their mother— nothing.
She has a trade to liue on. O let my dying breath
Beg this one mercie at thy bloud-staind hands:
Releeue them with now thine, once their owne lands.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Forgiue my deed, and by that mercie, I
Depend on for my sinnes; my mercy shall
Raise vp the children for the fathers fall. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: He's gone. Now vp againe. My wounds
Are slight, yet through their windows, heare I breath
Out all my malice. Noble youth, I loue thee.
How little of thy father hast thou in thee!
Now for some strange disguise, till time I find,
To pleasure him that was to me thus kind.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Well, I see there's no liuing in London, The foure winds haue conspirde to blow all the villany of the world thither. When I returnd from my short trauell, I inquir'd, for the knot of my old companions. But like an old Ladie, that has much vsd painting, how suddenly are they broken! I heard of three or foure in Bedlam. Fiue or sixe in Bridewell. Halfe a score ith' Counter. a whole dozen at Tyburne. But Oh, numbers, numbers, vnder the hands of Barber-Surgions. Some turnd Squires to a Brothell. Others walke New-gate lane. Some cheating in Ordinaries. Others prigging in crowds. And the rest, either swomme ouer sea, or drownd vpon a hill. Well, I do not like these proceedings; there bee so many rubbes. I could now begge in Dutch, but its no speeding language. Now my villanie failes on the sea, Ile trie what cheates the land has to worke on. I learn'd some scuruie medicins of our Surgion of the ship: & had no sooner set vp my bils in Bedford here; but a Goutie cure comes halting to mee. Fifty pounds I must haue to heale him. Fiue and twentie I haue in pawne: for the rest, Ile leaue it with the next Quacksaluer, that with more skill shall doe him as little good.
sp.stage: Enter Gripe halting, Nice and Thirsty.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Cousin Nice, and my man Thirsty.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Shall I fetch you some drinke, Sir?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No. Thy mind runs all oth' pot.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: So 't had need, for you keepe mee Thirsty, spight o' my teeth.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Goe you two to the vnder-Sheriffe; and bid him by vertue of this morgage, giue you possession of Vasters lands. The beggerly slaue has broken with me, and Ile take the forfeit. Go quicke, quicke. I will not lose an houre.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Ile but goe to the Church for a little holy-water—

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Be drownd in holy-water.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No, but a little sprinkled Sir. We shall haue the better successe in our businesse.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I pree thee good Nice, dispatch, dispatch.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: I, come, come master Nice. There's good licour it h' house. You may sprinkle your throte with that. Its better then holy-water.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: One thing Sir. I do not like going to day. Sure tis not a luckie time. For the first Crow I heard this morning, cryed twice. This Euen, Sir, is no good number.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Poxe o' Crowes and numbers. If thou hadst giuen her a peece of carrion, she would ha' cryed againe. Away.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: I go, Sir— stay, what if there be a Rauen about the ground?
Shall we then take possession? Oh tis an vnluckie bird.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Why, let her croke the downfall of his house.
What's that to me? prethee good Nice make haste.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay, too much haste will make one stumble: and that's no good signe.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Now, Valentine, Hast all things ready? how now— againe?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: A toy comes in my head.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Poxe o' that head: more toyes yet?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: How if a Catte sits on the Buttry hatch? Thou we'st proceed no further. My Grandam told me that a Cat sitting on the hatch, was an ill signe.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Mew. Beate her off, dash out her braines. Good Nice be not so curious.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Oh Sir, it's good doubting the worst.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Are all things ready, Valentine? this foole troubles mee worse then the gowte.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, the remedie is verie painfull. I could giue a tedious course of physicke, worse then any sicknesse. Keepe you fasting sixteene dayes together, saue the dyet I giue you. Binde you to the post of patience euery day tenne houres; and haue one still poure scaulding water on you: purge your very heart out: send your eyes out of their holes, to see how your feete doe: make your guttes barke worse, then an hundred dogges at a beare-bayting. But my medicine is sharpe and short, but passing sure. Sir, there be foure kindes of gowte.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: No more of kinds. There's no gowte kind to any man, I thinke, but to Physicians. Your remedy short-short.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, nothing: specially of no cost. Do y' see this ten-penny naile?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Yes: What of that?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: This naile I must driue through your great toe.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What? through the bone?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, bone & flesh too.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh-oh-giue me my money. This medicine's worse then any gowte. Oh good Valentine, your tent's too long— too long.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Then sit and rot: be rack'd still, Ile be gone.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Nay, good Valentine: would not a sixe-penny naile serue?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You'l be Physician, will you? If you'l sit downe and be cur'd, so: if not, farewell.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Nay, good Valentine:— euen do thy will.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Endure it manfully. It's but a brunt— so. nailes him .You shall sit but a quarter of an houre, till I ha' been at the Apothecaries, and then Ile loose you. Now farewell, gowty foole, Thou took'st no purge, yet hast a most sharpe stoole. Pray heauens, this kill him not. Well, let him sit. he takes away his purse with his keis And this shal go with me. I pray Sr take your case. This plot has tooke; try if some new may hit.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Come-come-Valentine. Oh never was man so farre in my bonds, as I am in this Physicians. H' has nayl'd me to him. That euery whore in London, were but i' my case now. Why Valentine—
Oh he's come. How now? are you return'd? where's my morgage? out Villaines, where's my morgage? Oh my toe— oh my morgage. I'm vndone.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Me thinkes you are too fast, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Plague o' you and your morgage. Oh my heart-it beats so, that it has broke my buttons. I would not bee so frighted againe to be made your heire. puffe.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What's the newes Thirsty? what, what, good Thirsty?

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Let me vndoe you Master.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No, not till I heare of my morgage. What's the matter? oh—

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: The matter? I would not ha' such another crosse, for all the crosses i' your purse.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What? oh— what? Is my morgage safe? Hath the vnder-Sheriffe done a miracle, and playd the honest man? what good Thirsty?

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Nothing Sir, but a Hare cross'd the way; and hee, poore timorous soule, durst goe no further for feare of sprights.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh rogues, pernicious villains, you conspire to couzen me: get out the naile, Thirsty. Hares, and Rauens, and Diuels.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Who has abus'd you thus Sir? could you be so credulous, to thinke this a receyte good for the Gout? Sir, giue me leaue to helpe you.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Do, good Ben but not in this, Ben not in this. Oh my morgage man, my morgage— run. I shall lose a dayes fruits of my morgage.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Come Sir, respect your health aboue your gaine.
I would not for your wealth haue halfe your paine.
Go in Sir, get some broth, looke to your wound.
Your morgage leaue to me, Ile keepe that sound.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Take my cousin Nice with you. Come Thirsty, helpe Thirsty.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Now for some cleanly tricke to shift my hands
Of this same shallow superstitious foole.
sp.p: Now couzen, I'am sure you are not without an Erra Pater i' your pocket. They say this is like to be a very strange yeare.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Most strange, and full of preposterous, prodigious, turbulent, dismall, fatall, amazing, terrifying—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Blesse vs. What?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Wonders. The effects whereof wil appeare in risings, partly biformed, and partly circular, on mens forheads, and womens mountaines.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Is there no sad mortality to ensue?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Yes, my Almanacke speakes of a most fearefull pestilence, especially to happen amongst Taylors and Gold-end-men.
Ther's a statute-lace shall vndoe them ifayth. A Taylours Bill shal be no more so deadly as the plagues.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Sirrah Nice, I had a dreame to night.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Passion o' my heart! a dreame? what? I do not like these dreames.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Ile tell thee what. Me thought, my troubled fancie
Led me into a Garden proudly deckt
With Natures glory, and the sweetest flowers,
That ere my breath suck'd vp: where the greene grasse
Tempted my sleepy spirits to soft repose.
There came, me thought, a friend (dead now long since)
And shooke me by the hand, and question'd me
Of many sad euents, whose conference
So vex'd me that I woke. Why stand'st amaz'd?
Thou wilt not leaue me Coz.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Yes, and you were ten Cousins. Dreame of a garden, and greene rushes, and a dead friends salutation? Cousin, make your will, be rul'd and make your will: you cannot liue.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Wilt thou be a foole of fate? who can
Preuent the destinie decreed for man? Ile on.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: So will not I. Good Coz, I leaue you to your destinie. The next newes I heare, the Lawyer's a dead man. Dreames quoth a! and he will not beleeue a dreame, he's an Infidell. One night I dream't that I found gold at a play. Next day I came thither, flatter'd with these hopes. Zlid, before the Prologue had done, I had lost my purse.
sp.l: Coz if you ha'no faith in dreames, farewell.
I would not dreame of heauen, lest I find hell.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: This charme has cast him off, now to my morgage.
Oh Vaster, thou art dead; thy haplesse issue,
Expos'd to the bleake ayre of these cold times.
I haue no meanes to expiate the wrongs,
My cruell Father, and my selfe more bloudy,
Haue done thee, but by charitie to thine,
All the poore pieces that remaine of thee.
So with the plaisters of our broken good,
We hide the wounds, first hauing shed the bloud.
Within there Hoh.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Thou com'st vpon thy death, infectious issue of the worlds plague; if thy bloud stained foote enter these dores. Our parents are from home. Till their returne, Ile keepe possession. Or lose it with my life.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Incensed Youth.
Thou fight'st 'gainst power with a sword of straw:
As good cope with the diuell, as with the Law.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Me thinks, Sir, there should dwell some pittie in your looke.
Oh, cast an eye of mercie on the woes,
Of two most wretched Orphans; doubly lost,
First in their Parents miseries: but, oh! most
In their vntimely deaths; for we doubt sore,
We neuer shall behold their faces more.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: My griefe requites you both.
No matter, had it so pleas'd the high powers,
If that my Father had excused yours.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Good Sir, forget your strength; and do not triumph ouer the prostrate fortunes of two wretches,
sp.l: Expos'd to vnresisted tyrannie.
Behold a Mayden begging on her knee—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Rise: that's heauens due. These armes now thee entwine,
That wish for euer, to be called thine:
A strange new influence runs through my affections,
Into my panting heart; and there inthron'd,
Commands my lower faculties to loue
This poore distressed Virgin. I am flam'd
With pittie and affection; whether more!
Yet let my senses some coole reason gather:
What, loue the daughter, and haue slaine the father?
(I must: heauen knowes I must). See, my lov'd friends:
My comming to you is for other ends.
My Father sent me to inuade your lands.
A while stand free redeemed with my hands.
There's money to relieue you: that done, you shall haue more.
Despaire not: heauen will not forsake the poore.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Right noble sonne of so profest a foe,
Heauen be as kinde to you, as you t' our woe.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I burst, if I containe my passion. Fairest Virgin,
If thou dar'st credite me, I loue thee.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Hold. Here take your kindnes back: Though we are poore,
My sister was not bred to be a whore.
Forbeare to touch her.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Fond Youth, thy rage is vaine.
Th'art young: thy errour doth thy vertue staine.
I loue her as a wife.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Oh doe not mock me.
How can I thinke, you to such fortunes borne.
Will looke vpon a Mayd, so poore, forlorne?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Alas! that pouerty should vertue smother.
Not in my brest. No, Ile still honest be:
Vertue in rags are gold's all one to me.
Censure me both, as you shall finde me true,
Ile be your father, and your brother too.
sp.stage: Enter old Gripe brought in a chaire, by Nice and Thirsty.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: So, let me downe, till I haue seene my new morgage.
How now son Beniamin, ha' you taken possession?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Of that you cannot dispossesse me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No knaue? what wilt thou take my lands before I'm dead?
You are a braue son indeed. But this is the world. If the father be poore, the sonne would be ridde of him, to saue charges. If rich, he must haue his lands ere his bones be cold.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: They may be cold, for they ha' been rotten these dozen yeeres.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I am very hungry.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: I am very thirsty.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: But dare not eate, because I was dream'd to night of choking.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Now brother w' are, vndone.
The damned father will peruert the son.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Gowt, dropsie, lamenesse, rotten legges can hasten
T'vndoe the poore. Vsurers that sit
Bound to their chaires with charms, & cannot moue
But by their porters, can to ill bestirre them.
He needs make haste, that is at hell before them.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Ha? for 3. Moneths?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Indeed Sir, by that power you put me in,
In charity to their miserable state,
Orphan'd of Parents, and of meanes to liue,
I gaue them 3. moneths profite of the lands.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Out Villaine, Charitie's a begger, as thou wut be. 3. moneths! three weekes, 3. dayes, 3. houres had been more charity, then euer I shew'd, or will shew to such beggers. Come Nice, Thirsty, list me: Ile take possession my selfe.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I hope Sir, you'l not nullifie my deed.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Deed mee no deedes: Ile nullifie thee from being mine heire. Come, helpe me I say.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, I dare not lift you against the poore.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Where's my man Thirsty?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: He's gone in to drinke Sir.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh he's a good knaue: he has got possession ot'h house.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Of nothing master but the Buttry, I.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: As lame as I am, Ile in my selfe.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sit still you lethargie: y' had better drop—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Containe your selfe, young friend. He is my father,
Let not the warme nest of my loue to you,
Hatch vp encouragement to my fathers wrongs.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You are my sterne Sir, at your pleasure guide
This tempest-beaten vessell.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Good Sir confirme
This worke of pietie, which I presum'd,
On faith of your good nature to affoord.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Sirrah, your good nature will bring you to th'Almeshouse. Thou shalt not inherit a doyt of mine. And for you two Kitlins, Ile make you mew ith Iayle, and there be any law in England. So this chasing fit hath got me the vse of my legges againe. Oh excellent Surgion; would thou wert here againe, for the other 25. pounds.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Strange! that same Quack-saluer has done him good, against his will. How fare you Sir?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: The worse for thee Bastard. Th'hast too much charitie in thee to be the sonne of old Gripe.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Deare brother, yeeld possession: wee'l begge rather,
Then this our worthy friend should lose his father.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sir, be not so incens'd: resume your sonne
Into your former loue, and I resigne
All right, that his free promise hath made mine.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Come then, Nice, Thirsty. Oh braue Surgion, I can goe.
Oh braue morgage I can enter.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: M. Beniamin, a sober word in priuate. If this wench want harbour, I care not if I giue her a nights lodging.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I haue inuited her with her brother to supper this night.
Will you—

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Oh it's Fry-day, and I know you haue flesh.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Thou wouldst take her any night. Is she not flesh?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Sweet Cousin, I would not eate her. If you please to commend me to her: let me see, for what— I leaue that to you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Goe in, let me alone. This petulant foole.
Shall be my scaffold to erect my plots.
Come, friends, vnlode your sorrowes on my heart.
Griefes weight is eas'd; when each one beares his part.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: THus am I stolne out from the Couent. Abbot,
Ly there, thou happy warranted case
Of any Villaine. Th'hast been my stawking-horse,
Now these ten months. So long 'tis since the Abbot
Went on a solemne pilgrimage and left
My brother, a good honest Fryer, his friend
Deputed for him. But my brother scarce
Warme in his new vice-honour, walking out
To visite me one morning, at my house
Fell dead of an impostume suddenly.
I bury'd him in priuate; but from's bloud
Am purer then the Crystall. Studying now,
How to turne sorrow into policie,
I haue assum'd his shape. Who can deny,
But that a Dunce may rise to Dignitie?
Blind Ignorance doth not alwaies strut in Sattin.
It often walkes a Clergy pace in blacke,
And deales the holy Rites with as bold hands,
As if it grasp'd Ioues thunder: and did iudge it
Enough to stare, looke bigge, and with a brow
More rugged then is Radamanths, denounce
Torrors against ill deeds: the whiles their owne
Are not lesse monstrous, but lesse broadly showne.
Thus in my selfe, how easie't is, I proue,
To sweat out iudgements 'gainst the sins we loue.
As if a garment of world-couzning grace
Were impudently good, set out by place.
Well, I get nothing by this borrow'd forme,
But countnance to my thefts. This hollow tree
Keeps all my holinesse: Lie there Abbot, till
My worke is done, then doe thou hide my ill.
Masse here's comes one already.

sp.speaker: Valent.
sp.p: Now haue I, like a Parasite, couerd my backe with braines. Out of my vsurers Gowtie toe, I haue spun a faire suite. I would faine heare, whether the diuell be dead or no. Yet I need not be so inquisitiue, for I'm sure he has giuen me nothing in's will. Now am I in quest of some vaulting house. I would faine spend these crownes, as I got them, in cony-catching. I ha'the game in sent, & will follow it with full cry.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Stand— Giue the word.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Word? what word? am I beleaguerd?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Few words are best among friends. Emptie your pockets, and you may vault the lighter. Quicke.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Th'art an honest fellow, a very honest fellow. In good faith I had no great need of mony; but since thou hast brought me some, Ile not refuse it.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Troth, I ha' but a little.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Faith nor I. we'll euen draw cuts, who shall ha' both.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Agreed.— Shall we breathe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Good fortune grant, you be able to pay me for this paines. In sadnes, I deserue double fees.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Ile make you plead harder, ere you sit downe to tell your money.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Looke that your case be good, I shall picke a hole in't else.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Well, let the law passe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not altogether so: lest we be both hange.— Stand your ground. Zlid, I cannot abide these running Cockes.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: I haue seene a runner winne the battell.— Shall wee draw stakes?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ha? a match— Throw by weapons, and lets embrace.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: I am a villaine, but I feare your clutch worse then a Seriants

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
As I'm true theefe, thou maist trust me. Ha sirrah!
Robin Hood, and the Pindar of Wakefield had not a stiffer bout. Shall we cling, like a couple of Eeles, not to bee dissolu'd but by Thunder?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Most liberally. Let's set vp shop together.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Done: & to begin our trade, behold a customer. Stand close.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: This russet-shape of a plaine-dealing yeoman
Spirits my hopes with boldnesse. Sharpe suspition
Like to a winking Iusticer shall see me,
And yet not see me. Thus with griefe-swolne eyes,
Ile match my wife, and childrens miseries.
This fiftie pound Ile husband like a Badger;
Buy and sell Barley: and so easily wind
Into the present passages of Bedford.
How good a schoolemaster is Pouertie!
I could not liue on hundreds, that came in
By annuall rents; now I begin to thriue
On the small fragments. Thus like Prodigals,
That once did scorne the meate, now glad of pottage.
The mannor gone, Ile trie to liue oth' cottage.
Bedford, ha' for you.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Stand. Giue the word.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: The word, y'are a theefe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You might ha' shot twice, and not hit it righter.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: What do you shoot at?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Oh Sir, like your Iesuite, all at the purse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Will you cast out the diuell, and saue's a coniuring.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Are you so cunning at the blacke Art? Ile trie your skill. What, both at once? that's no faire play.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Faire play is for Fencers. Yet thou seemst a good fellow. Thou shalt haue it. Stand aside, partner.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Saist thou me so, boy? then there's mony, win't and wear't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Now could I get in and rob 'hem both— Hercules! Hee laies about him like Orlando Furioso, or a coward turnd desperate. Braue boy yfaith. Wee might ha'robd two and twenty Taffata-clok'd rorers, before this freese-jacket. Oh, your surly Bore is like
a bloudy'd Mastiffe: when your spruce Pantaloun bawles like a whelpe in a Tauerne: yet at the sight of cold yron runs, as if he had seene a Serieant.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Hold, hold: Keepe your cash.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: The mony's good mony Sir, if it be not too heauy for you

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Nay, for the weight I could make shift, but for the scuruy conditions goe with it.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Hau you any gall to't Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not not so much as pigeon. Put vp thy cash my braue quintessence of Hobbniols. Giue me thy hand. How many thousand cudgels hast thou broken i' thy daies about a May-pole?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: I warrant, as many as would make all Bedford chimnies smoke a whole winter.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Iest on. Ha' you any more to say to me.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Nothing my braue Clem o' th Clough, but I would thou wouldst deale with vs. Say, shall wee put all our stockes together, and set out a ship of our owne?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Ha? first tell me truly what you are.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Agreed. Let's sit downe to counsell. I am the Abbot of Newnham.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: How? much?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Ile not bate you an Ace on't, till the old Abbot returnes from Pilgrimage. My chamber shall be our Rendeuous. The diuell himselfe in the shape of a blurting Constable wil not looke for vs there.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am a souldiour, and in this vacation time am forc'd to do like Lawyers; when suites do not make them, they make suites: because the warres will not maintaine me, I maintaine the warres. I set vp my Bils in Bedford here, for a Physician, and dealt with Gripe for the Gowt. I haue a proiect to swell our purses till they burst. Will you second me?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: As inseparably, as a condition does an obligation.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I haue often heard the gripulous Dotard talke of Fairies: and how rich the house proues that they haunt. I haue ripened the blister of his imagination to the full. Shall we launce it? I haue keys that shall secure our conueyance. Is't a match?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: The safest stratagem we could deuise,
By craft, more then by strength, all theeues do rise.
Of many politicke knaues you cannot spie one.
The Foxe will haue his prey before the Lion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Two or three nights we'le scatter some small peeces of siluer, till opportunitie plumpe our proiect.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: I take it rightly. Oh tis quicke and sharpe.
So with a Gudgeon lost, we'll catch a Carpe. A bootie.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: As I was saying, Master Bromley, why should you take th' aduantage of your neighbour Sager here? Y' haue got the reuersion of his Lease. Ther's is but one life to come in't. Wee are all mortall. It may come ere you looke for't. I loue peace, I loue peace.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: I say, that life is forfeit: and Ile enter on all. The law is on my side. Ile not be bound to th' peace.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: Nay Sir, Ile bind no man: but if I could perswade you— to be fleeced both, so I might be kept warme in your wooll— How say you neighbour Sager?

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: Alas Sir, I do but defend my owne.
Nay could be wel-contented to sit downe
With some (though vniust) losse. I iudge it best.
Though with some preiudice to buy my rest.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: Therein you wrong your selfe: the law is impartiall, like a Bell, as sound on one side, as on th' other, if the clapper be right. Master Bromley a word— What will you iudge me worthy of, If I perswade him to relinquish his right? You know your case—.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Here's twenty angels: worke it good Master Griffin, work it; and you shall be my euerlasting Atturney. But if you faile, you must returne.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: Pish, neuer talke o' that man— Mr. Sager, a word— I loue peace, though I cannot liue by't. I respect my conscience aboue my purse— when t' has no money in't.— What will you giue mee to draw Bromley to a good handsome composition?

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: Not a pennie, till y' haue done't.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: You know twill go against you, but I loue peace.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: (I neuer knew't in any of your Tribe.
Th' euent be what it will, Ile giue no bribe.)
Sir, as I like your end— God and my cause,
Are coate of steele, gainst the sharpe fangs of lawes.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Shall we walke on? our iourney's long.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Not so long as you take't. Stand, good Mr. Lawyer, shall I put a case to you now?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Come, vntrusse, we haue hast of businesse?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Quicke sirrah, I shall serue an Execution o' your throte else

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Indeed Gentlemen, I am sorry that I'm not better stored for you. If you had tooke me comming from terme, I could haue serued your turnes better.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: Bind them, hamper the rogues. Serue a Habeas corpus on that fieri facies.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: How happy were this common wealth! how sound!
If euery corrupt Lawyers fingers were thus bound.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Sager, I know thee poore: here take thy purse.
Though I rob these, no poore man shall me curse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Tarry till I lay the Lawyer in the midst of his clients.
Are your talons bound Harpy? Thou liest now like a Stallion new gelt, betwixt two Mares. This is a Distringis sirrah.
Farewell pettie-fogger.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Oh neighbours, I'am vndone, vndone.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Then helpe to vndoe me. Ile haue my action against the Rogues.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: Stay till you catch them master Bromley.
Well, somwhat this my falling state releeues:
That honesty speeds well euen amongst theeues

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Helpe, helpe. Good master Griffin, your breath's strongest, yawle, yawle. Your tongue could neuer stand your Clients in more stead.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I heard this way some mans distressed voyce,
Crying for helpe: some robbery. Oh tis no wonder!
A theefe and bawdy house are ne're farre asunder.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Oh good woman helpe, helpe to vntie vs.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: I know 'hem all. Two knaues, one honest man.
They know not me in this translation.
Come Sir, Ile loose you first, helpe you the rest.
Do well to all, but to the good do best.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Oh that I had the villaines vpon an execution now.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Would you turne hang-man, Sir?

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: I faith sweet wench, I would shew 'hem the law.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Oh pitie them: necessitie has no law.
Perhaps want forc'd them; though it was not good.
What Horseleaches are they, that full, sucke blood!
There is an Inne, enter, refresh your selues.
Their losse is money, yet I mone their state.
Who pities me most, most vnfortunate!
Robd of a husbands loue, now of himselfe.
How farre is this beyond all losse of pelfe!
He sold me hither; may that sinfull price
Of my deepe sorrow neuer preiudice
His happinesse, what climate euer holds him.
Be blest, sweet husband; let my ruine buy
Thy wishd content, though I forsaken die.
This witch has tyr'd me with her customers,
Whom I haue all sent home with betterd minds.
Against her vicious will, I force her striue
By vertue rather, then by lust to thriue.
I know, I am expected.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: The Iackes be now vncag'd, and flutterd hence.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: (The woman, that releasd them, I should know.
She frees them from this bondage to a worse.
There is no theefe, like whore, to picke the purse.)

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Shall we not shift ground?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: By no meanes. A theefes safest residence is in the same plat he did the robberie. There, of all places, the Cuckoldly hue will neuer crie after him.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: When shall we share the booties, and be proud,
How liberally our diuision mounts?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: The daies worke done, we'l cast vp the accounts.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Where's the pettie-foggers Portmanteau?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Lay't there. So, you shall see me catch a fat Pickerell, with this Gudgeon presently. Stand close.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Vncle, vncle, I had a certaine scuruy dreame to night.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Dreame? what of dreames? good cousin be not so nice.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I dreamt—

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Be you hang'd, Vncle.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Be hanged both, except I may haue some drinke.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Me thought I found a great deale of money.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: I would we had it, cousin, without dreaming.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Whoop master— no part of my finding.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No matter for a part: all's mine.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay, all's mine for dreaming.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Nay, all's mine for finding: and Ile keep't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Soft, sirrah: it lies there for a wager.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What wager, Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Marry, that who euer finds it, shall loose all the money in's purse.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Ile not meddle with it.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Ile ha' no part in't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Iudgement, Gentlemen: ha' they not lost the wager?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Vast. Lost, lost; as sure as Virginitie; no sooner laid then lost.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Come then to pay, to pay. (Sure this is Gripe, my Bedford-Gowtie-Vsurer. Plague o o' your stilts; what Carpenter set 'hem vpright? not my wimble, I hope.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh I am spoyld, spoyld; this tis to dreame of finding money— I knew, what twould come to.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Saue your labour, good master Theefe: for my breeches are ith' fashion, a great deale of pocket, but no lining.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: This is the rocke that split me. Oh good fate!
That thou hadst now about thee halfe my state.
Is't sinne to rob the Theefe? by vsurious course,
He once robd me, now I rob him by force.
No difference but this, twixt him and me.
I ha' not such protection, as had he.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh I am a poore man, a verie poore man.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Thou art indeed; wealth without vse doth free
No soule from the bleake stormes of pouertie.
Who cannot natures requests satisfie
Out of his wealth, his coffer's rich, not he.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Be they all bound to the good forberance?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Thus farre quits my reuenge. The Vsurer lies,
As fast in mine, as I am in his tyes.
Now let me kill him. No, bloud shall not die
My other sinnes in purple. Lye there. Loe!
That the wise lawe would serue all vsurers so.
How few in thy bonds didst thou ere vntie?
Now bound thy selfe, so without mercy lie.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Come, let's retire to our refuge.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Vncle, vncle. I would this all were but a dreame too.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Oh coz, I am damnd, damnd, my mony's gone.
Elstow morgage is lost. Wallow to me, Nice.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh vncle, its dangerous tumbling, snakes i' the grasse.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Wallow to me, Thirsty.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Master, I'm so drie, I cannot stirre my feet.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Helpe.—

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: More robberies yet? tis strange, how villains swarme!
Mischiefes hold close to keepe each other warme.
Three ranke corruptions make their neere abode.
An Abby, Bawd'house, and a Theeuish rode.
Where be these men distressed?— how? my Vsurer?
Shall I vnbind him, that hath bound my husband
In mercilesse fetters? Yes, I'm bidden, still;
With good deeds to requite my enemies ill.
Come, diuell, Ile vnlose thee.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Oh how I'm crost!
My mony, and my morgage, all, all lost.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Masse, a prety wench— If she lay thus bound before mee, I would not loose her, but vpon some conditions.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Will you go in Sir, and refresh your selfe?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Ile follow thee, sweete girle. Would I could cope This morgage, though my other be past hope.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Doe they brew wine here?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: See how this woman still me quits, and crosses.
I rob and binde, and she releeues their losses.
Why doth she thus? Its but a tricke of hers:
By charitie to draw in customers.
I am now patient, but more Cuckold still.
I helpe her to supply, gainst my owne will.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Shall we retire to my chamber, and share?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Tarry. Here comes another Iack-daw: let's plucke him, and take his feathers with vs— stand.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Thou durst not say so, were we on iust tearmes.

sp.speaker: Valen.
sp.p: You should bee some Lawyer, you stand so on your termes
Faith, we must change professions with you, you must giue's our fees.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Youle earne them first?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Braue Sir, so do not Lawyers alwayes.
But when you'r payd your selfe, you'l giue's our due.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Hold, Gentlemen, this is my friend.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Thine, noble Valoys? thou shalt begge his ransome then.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Hee stands secure. Haste to your chamber. There Ile meet you presently, and then wee'l share.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Are thy ends good in this giuen libertie?
Or dost it here alone to murder me?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Not with my sword, but with a tale shall wound thy amazed heart— come, let's sit downe.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: What tale? good friend, be plaine and short.
Woe to a heart, by expectation centuples the smart.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: I haue commendations to you from one Vaster: For by's description you should be the man.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Liues Vaster then?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: 'Las Sir, you know he's dead.
And by your bloudy hand was murdered.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: By me?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Is not your name Sir Beniamin Gripe!

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: You kill'd him, Sir. Poore man he dy'd
With penitence to heauen, to you remission.
Sayd, that you did it like a man, prouok'd
By his intemperate rage. Fate gaue that I
Keeping his walke, came to close vp his eye.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Heauen pardon me. What sayd the dying Vaster?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: He charg'd me seeke you out, and gaue me gold,
To bury him in secret; lest his death
Should hazard yours, and charm'd my silent breath.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: His loue giues fire to my greene pile of sorrowes.
May his bones rest in peace: in griefe I liue;
Lesse he and heauen do my blacke fault forgiue.

sp.speaker: Vaster.
sp.l: He hath forgiuen you, only this he begges;
That to the scatter'd pieces of himselfe,
Left to suruiue his miseries vncomplete,
His Widow and his Orphans, you would yeeld
Some pittie for your owne, heauens, and his sake:
And teach that hand, (from which he hop'd some good)
To succour theirs, that tooke away his blood.
He bad me tell you, now all meanes were gone,
To expiate that sinne, saue only one:
To hold those vp, that on the worlds sea swimme:
Since he had them vndone, you vndone him.
That you would be to them, as he should be:
This he bequeath'd you as a Legacie.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Ile be a iust Executor of his will.
Good friend, great thankes: my purse th'hast spar'd to ceaz
But what is worse, hast robb'd me of my peace.
Vaster, th'art dead: if thy transformed soule,
Could from the battlements of you high Tower,
Behold the vow'd endeuours of my heart,
To satisfie thy will and my huge debt,
In thee, to thine, thou wouldst my merit set
'Mongst thy best friends: yet narrow are my bounds;
To giue them plaisters, that first gaue them wounds.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Farewell Sir, thinke on Vaster.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Friend adieu. To Vaster and my vowe I will be true.
How thicke the sharpe pulse of my conscience beares!
How strangely my distracted Phantsie threats!
Oh vnappeased murder, that still keepes
The sensitiue committer from fast sleepes:
And murmurs in the eares a fatall knell
Of restlesse thoughts on earth, of worse in hell,
How deepe thou strik'st me with a silent blow!
Be patient heart, to thy fate humbly bow.
Fetch him againe I cannot; oh his sowne
Is too too mortall. Why then hurl'd I downe
My sinking spirits? Let me slye to mirth,
And burden cares with wine, to make them sinke.
The worlds rule is, Who feels the lode of conscience let him drink.
But oh importunate griefe! too hard it is,
To counterfet a false and forged blisse!
Yet once Ile force a tryall; I haue here an Inne,
I heare and wonder, is turn'd house of sinne.
Ile see, if the loose sprawles, with their sharpe wit,
Can giue my mind a medicine for this fit.
Whores I abhorre, as Gardiners Iayes: no matter;
Once for experiment, Ile heare them chatter.
sp.p: Preuention! I thinke here's one of the iourney-women come, to proffer me her seruice. Black prostitution! that any such face should euer waite vpon thee. Sister, what seeke you?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What is hard to find:
An honest man, or els my eyes are blinde.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Fut, if I say I'm one, I then fall short,
Of the occasion I intend for sport.
I'm such a foole in this Priapus-rode.
sp.p: Mee thinks, sweet-heart, your honest-man should bee one, that should please your appetite, stirre your veines, tickle your bloud, and make you laugh delight into your panting spleene.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: An honest diuell.
Th'are friends to hell, that tempt weake soules to euill.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Come, let me kisse thee— so: this was with ease;
Words are ayry shades, th'are deeds that please.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir, do not thinke to enter my chaste fort,
Encourag'd by this parle. You presume—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Not to vnlocke thy treasures with such keyes.
Gold only can surprise such holds as these.
And I haue that will doo 't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Then vse it well.
How's wealth abus'd, when it conducts to hell!
Sir, I will set no price on your desires.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: Ile be the franker Pay-master.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You must: Then pay me for my vertue: so Ile' take it.
What starues lust, is well bought; not what it feedes.
'Tis follies dregges, with coyne to buy ill deedes.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Come, come; why should you be so quaint, and nice,
That know what belongs to't?' Dsso, a Virgin
At thirteene, or perhaps a little vnder,
Could not with whuling nay's be so peruerse,
In her beworded Mayden-head.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: I must.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Thou dost not rightly of my merits deeme.
I would not know you such, as you now seeme.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: The golden footed law, that goes or runs,
Staies, and turnes backe, as we giue motion to it,
Shall step the pase, which thou would'st haue it. Nay,
Speake as thy tongue instructs it. I will change
Thy pouerty to gold, rich robes, a Coach,
And prauncing Coursers, that shall whirle thee through
The popular streets; and when thou sitst in pride,
The tamed law shall lacquay by thy side.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: These are some incitations to a heart
Tainted with malice, or that thinkes a heauen
In glorious ostentation; or would stand
Affected with the bane of prurient lust.
I'm of another temper. Pray you leaue me.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Thou shalt Nectar drinke:
Make ebrious waste of the sweet Gnossian wines;
Fesants shall be course dyet: refin'd marow,
Small pounded nuts, and losseng'd Amylum,
Scrap'd pearle and date-stones sprinkled on each slice,
And strew'd with sugar, like white frost on yce.
Grant me but loue, Ile raine a showre of Gold
Into thy lappe, out-shining Ioue, when he
Wrapt in his glory courted Danae.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Thy language does affright me. Oh my starres!

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: O let not teares spoile such a beauty. Tell mee; Why spill you water like a Crockodile, to captiue mee; that might haue don't with mirth, nimbler then ayre?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir, I haue no desire,
To take your lust, but pittie. Some what prompts my credulous heart, there is some goodnesse in you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: My truth shall quite thy faith, Impart thy mind.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ile trust you, Sir. I am a wretched woman,
The widow or the wife, I know not whether, of the distressed or dead Vaster.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How? I faint to tell thee; thou art then a widow:
The warres haue ended his infortunate dayes.
Nay, let not griefe oppresse thy spirits. Oh,
I haue kill'd the wife and husband with one blow.
Lift vp thy sowning eyes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Oh let me dye. Rather short death, then lingring miserie.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Reuiue thy heart: Vaster yet liues in me:
I am his sonne, that hath thy husbands lands.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: And can I looke for mercy at your hands?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Receiue this earnest; all my state is thine.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You cannot with these spels charme me to sinne.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I do not: when I taint thy chaster eares
With motions of blacke lust, pronounce me Villaine.
Tell me, who brought you to this Brothell-Inne?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: He, to whom heauen (I trust) hath clear'd all sin.
My Vaster sold me hither. I was content.
Thus to relieue his state, when all was spent.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: But couldst thou liue infectlesse in this ayre?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I haue, and will.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Will? This giues strange suspicion.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I made a promise, that without consent
Of her that bought me, I would not depart.
See where th' Inchantresse comes.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Now minion, you must be gadding. Cry you mercie, Land-lord: if you'l haue any sport, walke in, walke in. You shall take out your rent here, Land-lord. She shall be your own Vacation and Terme too, Land-lord.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: So, you pernicious Damme of lusts foule littour,
You that buy beauty and do sell 't againe;
And liue by th'occupation. Heare you? Free
This woman from your brothell slauerie.
Or I shall bring you to the cart and lash.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Oh I am cast away; she cost me fifty pounds, I ne're got foure grotes by her yet.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Thou shalt lose more by keeping her. Goe cleanse the house from this disorder, or I here discharge thee.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Good Land-lord, bestow her where you will. I am content to be rid of her, so I may hold your favour—
sp.l: Foxe pull your honesty. Is this the dancing mayde?
One more such purchase will vndoe my trade.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Hostice, Ostice, wher's your kinswoman?

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: Yonder Sir, talking with my Land-lord, your Worships sonne.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Son Benjamin? yea faith, are you so close with a wench? Come hither— she's a whore, Take heed on her.
sp.l: If she want mennes, bring her home: she shall keep my house.
Faith, I grow old, and cannot now long liue:
Oh such a Wench would be restoratiue
Perswade her Ben

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Ile do my best, Sir. See,
The pleased fates consent to succour thee.
My fathers house shall shelter thee vnknowne.
Please the old man with words, but hold your owne.
If my plot takes, as I can hope no lesse,
This lust of his shall thy good fortunes blesse.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: COme, sister to my sorrowes, and my selfe.
They say, society in woes doth lighten
Our pressures; but I finde the contrary.
My woes are heauier by thy companie
My griefe for thy distresse, doubles mine owne.
I should be farre lesse wretched, if alone.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Sweet brother. since we must both suffer, thinke it some comfort, that we share an equall fortune.
sp.l: Griefe has lesse power to worke on our sad hearts;
Where mutuall loues contend to beare their parts.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Little once thought thy mother, that thy fate
Should stoope to seruice to relieue thy state:
We are not try'd, but in our miserie.
He is a cunning Coach-man that can turne
Well in a narrow roome. To manage plenty
In a right forme, commends the state, not person.
Hee's blest, that to be rich can giue consent
With honestie, or rest poore with content.
I wonder, Benjamin doth not visit vs.
His last reliefe is done, if that spring drye,
We faint for succour, and must fainting dye.
sp.p: See, here comes Bromley, once our fathers Steward: Sure, hee'l support vs. Sister, cry his kindnesse: thy speech is more pathetical.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Theeues, Lawyers, Rogues, Harlots, and Inne-keepers, are mens purgations. Griffin has cheated mee: tooke twenty angels from me; theeues tooke 'hem from him. He promis'd to draw Sager to compound; now the day's gone against me.
sp.l: Oh I could wish my nailes turn'd Vultures tallons,
That I might teare their flesh in mammocks, raise
My losses from their carcases turn'd Mummy.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Good Sir, a word—

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Now Kitlin, what would you haue?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Sir, remember we are the miserable children of lost Vaster; whom once you seru'd.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: What's that to me?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, you can spare somewat to vs distressed.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: This is plaine begging. Minion, fall to worke,
And earne supply to wants with diligent labour.
For Vasters sake I will not vrge the Statute.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: The Statute, Iudas? w' are no Beggers, though
We try'd thy courtesie. Cursed be thy fate,
Thou from our father gott'st thy whole estate.
sp.p: Yet grudgest vs some fragments. Hence, out Dogge: If thou stay'st miscreant—

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Boy, Ile smoke you for't.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Do thy worst, diuell. An insatiate worme strike deepe into thy conscience, sile thy heart strings with rubbing frets: And turne thy derogated name,
sp.l: On foggy blastings of eternall shame.
Ingratitude is gone; and in his roome,
Extortion and a fiend is hither come.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I'm going to see my morgage—

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Good Sir, shew mercy on two wretched Orphans.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Out beggers, mercie? what dost talke to me of mercy? I'm going to let my grounds. I haue no leasure for mercy.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Goe thou accursed Cain: in miserie,
When thou begg'st mercy, be't as farre from thee.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Sir, y' have vndone our Parents; pittie vs.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I cannot stay to heare you, I haue businesse.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Heauen be as deafe to thee, when thy soule breath
Shall begge some respite at thy violent death.
This fellow sure will succour vs.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Iune, Iuly, August, September— the first day—

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Sir, raise our prostrate fortunes with some helpe: Some little helpe, you know vs.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I remember I haue seene you. Let's see— The fourteenth day— bad. I must do no deed of charitie to day; I haue president for it. 't is lost.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Now I remember, when I went to schoole,
I read of one Vespasian a good Emperour,
That told his Courtiers if a day out-slipt him,
Wherein he did nor good, that day was lost.
The next he would redeem't with double cost.
Ill colour'd sinne, how shamefull dost thou looke,
In them that plead thy warrant from their booke!

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Fourteenth day. A good turne forgotten. Oh here's learning from the starres.
sp.l: Though I do little good ere I am rotten,
Like citizens, I would not ha't forgotten.
Yet let me study on't: though a man may not giue, he
May buy, I hope without danger. Faire sister,
What shall I giue you for your maiden-head?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Thus much: a broken head.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Oh— Oh— Forgiue me, good Calender— I perceiue now, thy counsel's true. It's an euil day indeed: I should neither haue bought nor sold on't.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Hence, skie-consulting Gypsie: men commit
Sinnes darke as night, and blame the starres for it.
Another passenger— Oh this is Sager.
His wife was once a seruant to our mother.
Alas, when these built from our ruinous woe
Releeue vs not, what should this poore man doe.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: I long to heare from London; how my suite
Ends, or depends: if lost, I'm lost with it.
Who would trust any barres this tottring world
Can plot to fortify our wheeling states!
When the strong dores of Iustice may be broke,
Or lifted from the hinges by the force
Of politike engines: or the safest locke
Be pickt with a false key.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Sir, dwels there any mercie in your heart?

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: Yes: or of mercy, I must hope no part.
I know you, and your wants. My wife was once your Parents seruant.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: True, but that time is past,
And in her seruice now I would be plac't.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: That were too lauish yeelding to your woe.
I am but poore, troubles haue made me so,
Yet of that small life-blood, which my drencht state
H'as left it by the Lawes sharpe surgerie,
Embrace a portion, as your needs require;
And I may giue. Here comes your enemies Sonne.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I haue bene seeking all you three with nowes.
Good newes; friend Sager, the day's yours.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: It's welcome. I haue the better meanes to succour these.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: You haue preuented my request: I purpos'd
To beg that kindnesse of you. Robin, I would
Intreat you to accept my seruice, but
I meane the name of it: for in deed Ile vse thee
As my most equall and respected friend.
Nan, in thine armes I throw and locke my selfe;
My fortunes be all thine: the key's thy loue;
Let this kisse be the seale. Ye sacred powers
Make indissoluble this knot of ours.
Now, master Sager, giue her that respect,
You would my wife: all charges are my debt.
sp.p: Robin, you know the house; conduct your sister thither; that done, conuey these letters to the widdow Sorrow; (that's her borrowed name) she lies at my fathers.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: With iust hands.
I'm prouder of thy loue, then of thy lands.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Oh pure quintessence of thy profession.
How many hast thou robd, thus to make vp
Thy perfect godnesse! as if wiser nature
Had made an extract of ten thousand Lawyers,
And thrise refin'd it with immortall fires:
Then set it like a sanctified Lampe
On th' Altar of thy soule; to giue exemplar light,
In the dull darkenesse of this sinne-borne night.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Bromley's growne mad with rage: I'm iealous of him. You know the hopes of your posteritie dwell on your present fortunes: all which burne with the short Taper of your singular life, Say he should quench it.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: How Sir? murder me?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I cannot tell, it's but my jelaousie.
Tis not amisse, to keepe preuentions eye
Open and wary. Instruments of death
Stand ready prest to a malicious arme.
And policie, like a cunning Iesuite,
Watches behind that Arras for a call.
The deed once done, helpe it who can, or shall.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: What ground for this suspition find your thoughts?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: The fury of his madnesse, Enuies some,
That surges from the poyson'd auarice
Of his swolne heart: his broken resolutions,
Wherein his traitor-tongue can scarce forbeare
The protestation. Giue me leaue to feare.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: What will you counsell me?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: That must be study'd. Thus— Listen— We'll trie what mischeefes he can warpe: With woodden wasters learne to play at sharpe.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh my backe, my backe—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: How do you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh sonne, sonne, worse then euer. The Gowt was but a stitch to this. Oh the Collicke, the Collicke and stone.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: There be two of them master, aske the widdow else.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Sure it will rend my bowels out.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: It's iust: The stone ith' bladder now should make him smart That has so long bene sicke of stone ith' heart.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh that I knew where my old Physician liu'd.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Keepe on your habite. Our walke's turn'd Pouls, I thinke.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Zlid, if our third party were here, wee would venter on 'hem all. Th'are but welsh freeze; they would shrinke at the sense of yron.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Let's muffle vp our villaines with the shadow
Of some great conference: if a cheate be offer'd,
We'll not refuse: but now to compasse it,
Must not be done by force of armes, but wit.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Sonne Beniamin, you must to Goldington,
To view yong Brusters lands: th'are offer'd me
This morne in morgage. Harke you—

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Thirsty, come hither.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Ha'you any drink there?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No; but come drinke thy selfe drunke with Poetrie.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Faith, Poetrie now a daies will scarce make a man drink. I had as liefe be a pot as a Poet: then I should sometimes be full of good liquour.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh, your Poet is too full of that, it makes him thred bare. Sirrah, I ha'made a Sonnet here to my Mistresse; she n'ere wrought such a one on her Samplar. Lay thine eare close to my musicall tongue, I shall rauish her.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: You shall be hang'd for't then.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: Open thine eares, like an Oyster a sunning
Euen as the bird, which we Camelion call, doth liue on aire for aye:
So my kinde heart, euer like a stocke-Doue shall feede on thy loue all day.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: I, and all night too.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I, and all night too: but that night would make the verse too long. Now I talke of night, let me see what time of day it is. I haue businesse, must not be rim'd away.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Pray y' Sir, how speakes your watch? One? mine lies inclining to two You haue a prettie interpreter of the time there. Who made it, French or Dutch? You need not doubt me, Sir, I am the new Parson of Saint Peters in Bedford.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Sir, then as I may say, haue ioy in your new Benefice, for belly-peece you must ha' none. Pray' lets peruse your watch, see you mine.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Fezz 'Sir, y' haue a braue wash there. Ihill warrant the Kings wash-maker made it. Beseech you master Nice, let me see master Parson wash. Master Parson will you zell your wash, Ihill giue you good cash for it.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: No, my honest friend, I will not sell it.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Will you runne with me for it?

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Runne? no.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Cheuore ye runne for't, you shall nere ha't else.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Oh my watch— Nic. Oh my watch.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Stop the theefe, stop the theefe.
sp.stage: Vaster runs away with Curfews watch: Curfew with Nices.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Stop the Priest, stop the Priest.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Let him go, he runs for a wager.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How now? is my cousin Nice playing at Bace?
I know one of them well, by his sad tale
Of Vasters death: for that Ile not pursue him.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Son, I did rest me, hoping to go forward.
But so increase my paines, I am not able.
Suruey you Brusters lands, and speed returne.
All's for your good, for I am now out-worne.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I goe Sir— All's for me; yet while she liues,
And his hydroppicke spirits can looke through
His bodies loope-holes, and conuey the pleasure
Of his contemplate gold, his lusts sole God,
Through those windowes to th' admiring heart:
Nothing comes from him; not the superfluities
Of basers things, not being first improu'd.
I am his onely issue, and on me
I thinke he meanes to settle all his state.
It's the onely way to giue me curst and poore,
To build my nest on such extorted store.
Those fathers, that distress'd mens ruines vse,
"As scaffolds to build vp their racked wealth,
" Proue in the end, like citie-houses, that
"On small foundations carry spacious roofes:
" When the incensed heauens in tempests frowne,
"Their owne top-heauy weight tumbles them downe.
" The first or second generation spils
"By ryot, what by wrong the father fils.
In this Ile be a mirror to these times:
And by the hand of charitie returne
To euery man, what by his couetous rape
Their states are rauish'd of: so worke my rest.
Th'ill gotten gone, that which remaines is blest.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh Thirsty, honest Thirsty. Thy old master is but a dead man. I cannot pisse man: my vrine's stop'd.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: You should drinke, hard, master: all this comes with pinching your selfe of your liquour. This is the reason, that so few Dutchmen are troubled with the stone. Your miserable Churle dribbles like the pissing Conduit: but his iouiall sonne with a streame like Ware-water-spout. This is the cause, the Vsurer falling sicke, so seldome rises by the staffe of Physicke: for he has no water for the Physician to cast.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Now the Gowt, Dropsie, Lethargie take possession of their legs. I ha'lost my wind, and my watch, and I feare, my wench too.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: You haue watch'd faire: sure that Parson was some Irishman.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Some hangman vncase him. I ha' bene at the Parsons, and he's no such manner of man.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What crew's this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Blesse your worship: I am your Worships sonnes Tenant. I ha'brought a rogue to your worship, to be examin'd.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: What fault hath has he committed? Clarke, to your office: take his examination. Now neigbour Sleepy, are you Constable?

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: A good harmelesse Constable, a theefe may take him napping.

sp.speaker: Marm.
sp.p: An't please your worship, the rude Raggamuffin comes into my house, cals for drinke; and when the Tapster came with a reckoning, he broke the pot about's head; because he had not a cleane Apron on.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, because he misreckoned me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Whose fault was it, to wipe out the score?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not mine. Indeede I anointed the score with butter, and the Tapsters owne dog lick't it out.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Vncle, vncle, as sure as my watch is lost, this is master Valentine the Physician.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh Coz, that it were true. Pray' Sir, let me mooue a question.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You may command my answer Sir, y'are a Iustice.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Were not you the man, that heald me o' the Gowt?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Troth Sir, I haue done so many cures, that I forget a number of my patients. Th'other day I cured a lunaticke
Cobler, pitifully run out at soule, when hee was giuen ore by the Physicians. I let him bloud, tooke three Hen-egges, suck'd 'hem out, into the shels I put his bloud, set them vnder a brood-Goose. When she had hatcht the rest, I gaue these three putrified egges to a Dogge: the Dogge grew madde, the Cobler sober. And now my memorie runs backe, I call to mind one of Bedford, sicke of the Gowt, whom I cured.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I am the man, my renowned Paracelsian: thou shalt haue the other 25. pound. Constable, I discharge you. Ostice, I'le see you payd: set your recknoning on my score: trouble me no further: leaue vs, leaue vs. Now my deepe diuer into the secrets of nature, I haue a cure for thee, more desperate then the former.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What is't Sir, that my Art cannot extend to?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: The stone, the stone: I am pittifully grip'd with the stone, I ha'lost my pissing.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, the disease is somewhat dangerous.
Yet if that your expulsiue facultie
Retaine true force, I'le warrant to make you pisse.
I must awhile withdraw to study Sir.—
Now am I puzzled: bloud, what medicine
Should I deuise to do't? It must be violent.
Giue him some Aqua-fortis; that would speed him.
Let's see. Me thinks— a little Gun-powder
Should haue some strange relation to this fit.
I haue seene Gun-powder oft driue out stones
From Forts and Castle-walls, huger then he
Has any in his reynes or bladder, sure.
Faith, 'cause I am a souldier, I'le make triall
Of that same blacke and vaporous Minerall.
I'le shoote into his belly: if the gunne hold,
I'le giue him charge enough: some Aquavitae
First brewd together would allay it well.
Ile sweare to try it, if I doe not misse,
By a strange tricke Ile make my Vsurer pisse.
Sir, Ile goe in and prepare for aou.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p:
Doe so. Here, Thirsty, there be the Keys of the Buttry:
attend vpon him good Thirsty: let him lacke nothing, as thou lou'st me.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: I loue you Master, but here's a good key I loue better. Sweete instrument of my ioy, let me kisse thee. Alas, that thou and I should be such strangers. Wee ha' but one barrell: now if that should bee in my masters disease, troubled with the strangullion, and could not runne— well, if it bee not emptie, Ile giu't a scowring.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Now if this rare wonder of leaches can cure mee of this griping, that I may haue some fortie or threescore yeares more to gather in, by that time I shall gather enough to keepe me all the rest of my life. When a man growes vp to to sixe or seuen score, it is high time to thinke of mortalitie, and to take some ease. These three or foure nights I ha' bene haunted with Fairies: they dance about my bed-side, poppe in a peece of gold betweene the sheetes, scatter here and there fragments of siluer, in euery corner. I keepe my chamber swept, cleane linnen, fire to warme them euery night. I was at first a fraide, they had beene spirits; now I see, they are good harmelesse Fairies. If I can please them, I shall grow rich, rich.
Sonne I haue stayd for you.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: You haue done your health the more wrong, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: How dost like my morgage?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: It's a faire liuing, Sir; but I would not haue you meddle with it.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Why, my wise sonne?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Oh Sir, good deeds are scant,
When we aduantage take of poore mens want.
sp.p: Bruster's an honest man; lend him some money without such sharpe securitie.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Not a doyt. If he come to me, and conuey the morgage I haue it ready; els I haue no money.
Sonne come and sup with me.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I follow, Sir. Preposterous transuersion of our selues!
Th'erection of our faces should instruct
Our groueling thoughts t' ascend. How do men thwart
The teaching hand of Nature, and our birth!
Our heads cut aire, and yet our hearts plow earth:
I looke for Sager here. He's come.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: Heer's my owne case and counterfeit; by this dangerlesse plummet, we may sound the depth of his more close and intricate stratagems.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: So wiser masters lay some easie baites,
At once to tempt and trie their seruants truth.
The subiect for quack-saluing Empirickes
To exercise their inexperience on,
Should not be men, but malkins.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: Do you thinke, that he would doe me violence asleepe? would he not wake me to some conference?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: No, hee's a most ranke Coward; and I know,
Dares not come neere thee, though thou wert asleepe.
If he does ought, he'l do't by that long Engine.
Conceale your selfe awhile. How fares my name?
How does she brooke my slow-pac'd comming to her?

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: Faith, in your constancie lightens all griefe.
She neuer heares you mention'd, but she startles:
As if your name like some celestiall fire
Quicken'd her slow-pac'd spirits with new life.
I neuer knew vertue and beauty meete
In a more happy mixture. I remoue.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I loue her freely: shee's to me as th'ayre.
Her beauty is best and blest, whose soule is faire.
The Wolfe is come.
sp.stage: Enter Bromley with a fowling piece.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Good euening to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: My wish requite you.
You walke to haue a shoot, Sir: I depart.
I would be loth to preiudice your sport.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Saw you not Mr Sager, Sir, of late? This is his walke: I would faine speake with him.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Why would you speake with him?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Sir, for no harme.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: I do not thinke you meane it; but you know, hee's valiant like a Lyon: if crosse words should stirre your blouds to quarrell— Sir, take heed. Hee'l be too hard for you, and your long weapon. This medow is his euening walke. Farewell to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: Good night M. Beniamin; you need not doubt me.
If I could meet him at th' aduantage now,
He is the Fowle I'd shoot at. His life done,
The Farme is mine. Oh ye, whose hopes depend,
Like lingring shadowes, on anothers end,
What need you waite with patience natures leasure,
When such an engine can soone work your pleasure?
Tarry: yonder's a man— now by his habite
It should be Sager. What? and fast asleepe?
Wish'd opportunity to my reuenge.
Ile kill him ere he wakes. Stay, grant he should
In this vnbeaten medow lately act
Some horrid sinne, please his adulterous lust:
I should then with his body strike his soule,
And sinke them both together. Reason no further
Thou chiding conscience. See, the Fates haue plac't
Him fit for vengeance: enemie, sleepe thy last.
Hee's Planet-strucke, falne downe: now to my Farme.
He that would rise, must thanke his wit or arme.
Oh but my murder! pish, who euer stood
