In fortunes height, without some touch of blood?
sp.stage: Enter Beniamin and Sager at seuerall wayes.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: This I diuin'd.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.p: Happy preuention!

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Goe, thou despairing wretch, and for thy will,
Ten thousan swords shall thy vex'd conscience kill.
'T was a vaine blow to vs, and no bloud spilt,
Not lesse in thy intention is thy guilt.
This Clergy-habite which you haue assum'd,
Make good a while for your supposed death;
Allow his tyrannie free scope: liue close:
Till time shall ripen those euents, we striue
To build on this vile ground. Hold, ther's my key:
Into my chamber; I sup at my fathers.
What, come againe?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: I cannot be at rest: I must needes see,
If this late murdered corps remoued be.
Some gold I haue put vp in this Portmantua:
If I should be pursu'd, this may relieue me.
Ay me! the bodi's gone: sure it's reueal'd:
Murder from heauens eye cannot be conceal'd.
What shall I doe? sit downe: lye there, my gold.
sp.stage: Enter Nice, and Thirsty, on either side, crying So ho.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Holla, Cousin Beniamin. So ho ho.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Oh ho ho.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Oh me, the Countrie's vp, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: This foole hath frayd him.
Oh guilt! how hast thou made
Cowherd of man to fly at his owne shade!
Now Cousin Nice, what holla you for?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: You had need of a bell to ring you in. Your father has stayd supper for you this houre.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Come then, let's walke on— what's here a Portmantua?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh, oh, do not touch it: it's venome.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Why my wise Cousin? why are you so timorous?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh it lies there for a wager: there be theeues about it. Take heed Cousin; I found a Portmantua once, and lost all the money in my purse. Fly, fly—

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Are you gone? Well, I see now, hee that will be wise by Calender, shall be a foole by destinie.
sp.l: Sure, this is Bromleys budget, and has gold
Put vp for his escape: 'tis so by th'weight.
It falls into my hands most luckily:
For I haue need of cash in these occasions.
Yet Ile repay't againe: my honestie
Shall be his friend, whose feare was friend to me.
Oh, in this glasse my represented soule
Stands manifest to my impartiall eye.
Ye heauens rayne showers of mercy on my sins:
Lest where my pleasure ends my wo begins.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: RVnne faster, ye dull legges of motion,
That time may follow with a swifter pase.
Let wanton Epicures wish you creeple-limbes,
Insatiate with the ryot of their ioyes;
And chide the hasty forwardnesse of day,
That will not dance attendance on their play.
My spirits wrought vpon with tedious woes,
Thinke that each houre lingring and lazy goes.
Impartiall fates, how you delude our thoughts!
Guiding euents to their determin'd ends,
Whether our strength with or against contends.
Whether the passenger wake, or sleepe his fill,
The waue and wind-mov'd vessell goes on still.
Patience then heart! they do not valour know,
That weary faint, but who can suffer woe.
Who's this?
sp.stage: Enter Rob. Vaster with the Letter.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: By your leaue, Mistris Sorrow.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Right, th'hast hit my name.
Yet cleare of sinne, my sorrow has no shame.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I haue letters from Mr. Ben Gripe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: They're welcome. (poore boy how am I vndone!
Tis hard, a mother must not owne her sonne.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sure I should know that face and language too.
A chill disquiet troubles my soft peace,
And runs like a cold feuer through my bloud.
I'm very sicke of somewhat. Oh 'tis then
Errour, the sicknesse in all minds of men.
But that I know her absence giues her dead.
I' would sweare it was my mother. 'las vaine thoughts,
How you would flatter me!

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: — Your prouident friend, Beniamin Gripe.
Leaue out that Gripe: it's an vnproper name;
Cannot denominate thee for such a creature.
A name can neuer constitute a nature.
If blessed mankinde haue a Phaenix left;
And vice of that good hath not time bereft;
In this degenerate worlds apostacie;
The plurall number's lost: that one is hee,— Sonne

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Zlid she calls me Sonne.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: That word's oreslipt.
How easily loue is in her language trip't.
Sonne— of compelling nature not forbeares:
Passion must vent it selfe in speech or teares.
Dost thou not know me?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Yes: this testifie.
I begge your blessing on my humbled knee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Rise with heauen's benediction.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Liues my Father?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Guesse by my greefe and silence.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Vm'h my doubts
Wrappe me in further maze. My father dead?
My mother liuing in his enemies house?
Let's study. Oft I haue heard my father mone,
That this same womans lust had him vndone.
This giues strong faith. Why should shee els liue here,
But to some such vile end? By heauen tis cleare.
Oh that this sappe, which my life feedes vpon,
Did not confesse a deriuation
From that corrupted trunke! Well, I will force
Nature runne backe with a preposterous course.
Ile fashion a forgetfull lunacie,
That ere I was her soone. But on my soule,
Not touch her with least hurt.— Woman come hither.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Woman! Deare Robin, not thy mother? blesse mee.
Why dost thou gripe me thus? Oh some blacke storme
Is rising on thy brow.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Storme? No, tis thunder. Can you read this?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes, I can spell't too well. It speakes my death, deare sonne—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Come, come, forget
These filiall rights, and Natures attributes.
Prepare your selfe to—

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What? Oh desperate child.
Oft haue thy bended knees with a iust dutie
Kiss'd the cold earth, to begge my prayers to heauen,
For thy prosperity: oft desir'd forgiuenesse
Of thy wild infant-errors. Oft haue these
Borne thee with soft indulgence: but now, see,
A wofull mother bends her humble knee
To her incensed sonne; not to conserue
This flesh from death, but thy black soule from hell:
Th' vnscaped dungeon, where all Parricides dwell.
Thinke: if thy spirits be not growne mad and wild,
Pitie a mother kneeling to her child.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I'm deafer then an Vsurer to your mones.
I must, like Nero, see the place I bred in.
Be briefe in answere: did you neuer wrong my fathers nuptiall bed.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Take heede.
Clogge not that brest with more sin, that must bleed.
Speake truth and saue your soule.
Lye you not here to satiate his lust,
That robb'd my father? speake, or y'are but dust.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: No on my soule.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Now on thy soule thou lyest.
Confesse, be plaine, or without pawse thou dyest.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Helpe, heauens or men.
sp.stage: Enter Benia. Valentine, Gripe, Nice, Thirsty.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: What prodigie's this?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nothing Sir, alas nothing: 'twas but my feare.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: It is my seruant Sir; he meant no ill.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Sonne, sonne, howsoeuer he serues you, I'm sure he does not serue God. Without question, he would haue rauish'd her.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: He would haue refresh'd her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Speake widow, is 't not true?— away with him.
Cousin Nice, make his mittimus.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: It's not amisse to let him feele some smart.
His life they cannot touch: what his offence
Deserues in heauens, strict iustice, mercy pardon.
Parents learne this in tendring Childrens state:
Too much indulgence is not loue but hate.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Sure his complexion doth not giue it: let me see your hand, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Will you feele it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: (Sonne offer violence to the mother?) strange!
Till I can sound this mysterie of ill,
Ile to the prison and relieue him still.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: You will be gone Mr. Valentine; but I hope you wil visit me shortly againe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Before you looke for me, Sir,— if all fall right,
I vowe to visite you againe this night.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Ha widow! I am cleere of the stone now.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: The lesse able to do a widow pleasure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Tut, wench, I meane the disease, the disease.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: (No Sir: you haue a worse disease behind:)
The body hath no sicknesse like the mind.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p:
Try me, sweet. I'm like a leeke, though I haue
a gray head, I haue a greene— wut? wut be my medicine for the stone? when? when?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: When you haue married me I will be your wife.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Pish: first make triall how thou likest me: there is no wit, to marry before experience.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Your house Sir, is too publike.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Hold, ther's the key of my closset. Be thine owne pandar for conuayance. I must receiue a little money: profit is aboue pleasure: about ten—

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Good lucke direct my hands vnto the morgage.
That found, if or my witte or strength hold tacke,
I haue a medicine Sir, to coole your backe.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: 'Las poore wench: now shee's got into my Closset, she hugges her hopes, as a Polititian his ayery plotte, and cryes a prize, a prize. She shall be double cony-catch'd. Wel, it growes Fairy-time. Oh the fine dapper laddes, how they friske about my chamber: when at euery step here droppes a grote, there a teston. Many drops make a floud. Sure, I'm some wonderfull honest man, that they loue me thus. I must to bed. Tarry, how then shall I keepe touch with the widow? Tha't, Ile sit downe in my chaire, and faine my selfe in a slumber. Oh 'twill be a golden waking dreame.
sp.stage: Enter Vaster, Valentine, Curfew, like Fairies, dancing antickes: pinching Gripe, as they passe by him.
sp.p: Oh-oh-th 'are angry. Would I were rid of 'hem. Oh— sweet spirit— oh— doe not terrifie mee thus. What haue I done to prouoke you?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Confesse thy sinnes. Th' hast some wench in a corner.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I haue, I haue— oh— but Ile not meddle with her.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Whiles thy house was cleanly swept,
And thy conscience chastly kept:
Neat linnen, fire and water ready;
And thy purpose good and steady:
Whiles thou neuer sentst the poore
Vnrewarded from thy doore.
Whiles thou wakendst with the chimes,
Because thou wentst to bed betimes,
We brought thee wealth; but twas in vaine:
For now we'll fetch it backe againe.
Come deliuer the keys of your trunkes.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh theeues, you'll robbe me, you'll vndoe me.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: No, Gowtie blister, well bind thee, vndoe thee, who will—.

sp.speaker: Val
sp.l: Open thy iawes thou yawning sepulcher:
Here is a morsel for an Vsurer.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: A peece of Cheese of the Low-country Dairies.
This is the vsuall diet of the Fairies.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: Now we will rip the lining of thy trunkes.
Better the Fairies haue it then thy punkes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Lucke more, then we can carry, hath assign'd vs.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Each horse his lode: we'll leaue the rest behind vs. Thou greedy Panther.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sauage Wolfe.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Man-eater. Thou setting Canker.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Commons horsleech.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Cheater

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Whose belly has iust cause to sue an action
Of trespasse, gainst thy couetous lusts exaction:
For destinie of many hundred meales,
Which it from others, and thy selfe too; steales.
The Gowt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The Dropsie.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: Collicke, Lunacie,
Like Sprites and Fairies haunt thy company.
And as thou gap'st now, let some Batte or Owle
Spet backewards i' thy mouth.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: No more. If thou do not
Repent, restore, turne good, sit till thou rot.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What does Vsurie sticke in thy teeth? spet out, Dog, spet out. Now thou gap'st for a morgage. Dost?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Fare-ill. To those that aske how came this euill, Giue answer thus: The Fairies robd the Diuell.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Oh— Oh— Oh.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: Ho master Gripe? what, your chamber doore ope thus early? how now, bound? gagg'd? what rogues ha' bene here?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Speake to mee vncle, speake: the gagge's out.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Saue the gagge. I will hang the whole shire, but Ile find 'hem. Iugglers, Fairies, incarnall sprites! My money, my heart, my guts, my soule— Let me curse my selfe into the ground, and saue a Dirge. Run, cry, ride, charge the Constables with 'hem.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Where be they, Sir?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Gone to the Diuell. Runne to a Coniurer, cast me a figure.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, all the Coniurers are o' their owne trade. A mischiefe on't, I thought there was some scuruy luck towards; the Crickets did so cry ith' Ouen yesterday. And this verie houre, as we came in, there was an Owle whoo-whooping in the top of the chimney: and iust at the threshold, master Bromley here stumbled Signes, signes.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Plucke downe the signes. Ile vndo all the Innes in the towne: they harbour the theeues.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: You said they were Fairies.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Now in sinceritie, I heard a great ratling of chaines.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: (This makes mee wonder! such a robbery, and I not heare it?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Come bridle vp this furie. What will you say, if I can produce you the plotter, abbettor, or at least accessary to this villanie? What if the pick-locke can open the chest of all this stratagem?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: 'Las, poore widdow, she was fast, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: No, she was loose I warrant you: how could we haue got in, if she had not open'd the dore? Your cousin Nice and I came from a hurly-burly ith' Iaile. Your sonnes man has broke from his keeper. And as we were comming, wee met this woman verie supitiously stealing out.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: My heart misgaue me thus: this diuels tongue
Would worke my misdeem'd innocence some wrong.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: No more words. Cousin, neighbor, take her to the next Iustice. I must not deale in my owne businesse. Let her bee examin'd soundly, soundly: sent to the Iayle, roundly, roundly.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: No more. Do not you know, I know you for a whore!
Away with her, I will not heare her speake.
My gold, my siluer— Oh my heart will breake.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Come, will you walke? Ile leade, widdow, come you next. Master Nice, you'll follow.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: As close, as beggery followes drunkennesse.
Let me see your hand, widdow— Oh the case is cleare.
A yellow spot doth on your hand appeare.
Gather vp your heeles, widdow: Iustice Surly dwels hard by.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: How now? my mother guarded? with two rogues?
Sword, thou didst faine to kill her— but— Sirrah— you— deliuer me this woman, or Ile make thy yellow starch'd face serue me for a cut-worke band.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Oh Sir, y'are well met; you broke from the Iayle last night. Apprehend him master Nice.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I'am somewhat dainty and shy on him, Sir. He lookes vile sharpe on't.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Let him looke as sharpe, as an Apparitors nailes, we'll blunt him I warrant ye. Sirrah, I charge you stand.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sirrah, you see I stand charg'd already. Will you haue me run?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Oh helpe, helpe—

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I ha' not made my will.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: No matter for thy prayers; dispatch it quickely then.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: You'l giue me leaue, Sir, to make my will.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Then my will is— to runne away.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Thankes, sonne; but now do you not, like the Lion,
Saue the distressed Lambe from the Wolfes pawes,
For sacrifice to his owne bloudie lawes?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Deare mother, pardon; be secure—
sp.stage: Enter Bromley, Nice, Beniamin, Sager disguised, Anne Vaster.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: This way, this way: here— Oh haue we found you?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: How do these mischiefes flutter in thicke heapes!
And cloud my vnderstanding from the light,
I look'd the Sunne should shine, find it darke night
I cannot stand t' examine circumstances.
Now master Bromley, whither are you bound?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: Your father gaue vs charge to haue the widdow
To master Iustice Surly's; he suspects her
To haue some hand i'th robberie to night.
Sir it concernes you; he has lost 300. pound.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Vmh. My father robd? the widdow charg'd with it?
Her sonne vniayld himselfe? these are harsh turnes.
Well, go you two before, prepare the Iustice.
You haue my word for their appearance. Go.
Widdow, and Robin, now here's none but friends:
You'l giue me leaue to wonder at these ends.
Of that anone.
Meane time I here present you with a gift,
Dearer to me, then is the Sunne to earth.
So; narrow vp your passions for a space:
H'you the morgage-deeds? giue them my hands.
Yet the successe on my invention stands.
Mother, and brother, (so I hope your titles)
My selfe, and friend here, whom you do not know,
Will baile you both. That done, I haue an Inne,
Now voyd of Tennant; there dwell all together.
My friendship to the power shall pledge your faith.
Measure good deeds by what man would, not hath.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: What Damn'd fortune's this, that I cannot smell out these theeues? I would sweate them to the Gallous, as well as they swore me out of my money. An oath like a strong charme, should coniure their neckes into the circle of a rope.

Oh, here comes my fellow-Patient; wee both tooke Physicke together; purg'd, purg'd: but I haue a cordiall for him. Saue you, brother Gripe. Mr. Bromley, newes, good newes. It's reported, that Sager's dead.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Dead? Ile go take possession presently.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Do not with too strict rigour exercise your power on his distressed family.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: My time is come, I will not lose an houre.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: It's iust, that euery man should take his owne.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Sir, you speake law, not charitie. He that will
Be nothing more then iust, is vniust still.
Wo to that quited soule, to whom from heauen
All iustice, and no mercie shall be giuen.
Your mercy to the widdow, to the Orphans.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: As much as a Puritan has vpon a good feast.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Well— let me tell you this— Sager is dead.
So flies report, borne on presumptions wings.
But how he dy'd, that aerie bird not sings.
Kild— but by whom— waight deeply— I must hence.
The muttring's strong— looke to your conscience.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: How's this? kild?— muttering? and conscience? Looke, his ghastly melancholy points him out for the murderer. As sure, as a hatte-brinkes puld downe declares a cuckold, this darkenesse discouers him.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: I am a villaine.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Tell him, that knowes it not.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: My narrow heart cannot be capable
Of this huge bulke of sorrow. It must out.
Now, to whose bosome better then my friends?
This hand kild Sager.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: Nay, do your worst.
Twas but chance medley, accidentall slaughter.
Intending with my Peece to strike a fowle,
Against my will the cocke went downe, and he
Stood in deaths way. It was his destinie.
But Griffin, harke you— let not your tongue stirre.
Do not I know you for a forgerer?
And more— you wot— let not your tongue be loose.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Thus are two Foxes catch'd in one poore noose.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.l: Our guilt shall bind our secrecie; who liues
An vnsuspected villaine, winks at others
Vnlawfull deeds, to teach their eye-lids how
To winke at his— Shall we go to our new Hostice?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Where? who?

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: For your where, at the Maiden-head, a good likely place. For your who: the widdow that old Gripe suspects for the robbery; but young Gripe hath tenanted to his Inne. Masse, she preuents vs. Widdow, we were comming.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Pray' Gentlemen walke in; you shall haue attendance.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Your company, sweete widdow.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Ile not be long from you, Sir.
Oh, some retiring from this house of sinne.
Fate! I was neuer bred to keepe an Inne.
sp.stage: Enter Curfew, Valentine as themselues, Vaster disguis'd.
sp.l: More customers? that which all Innes would see;
Great store of guests: this is a plague to me.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Yonder's mine Hostice. Now the water's vp, that we cannot get ouer to the Abbey, it is our securest course to commit the money to her custodie. If any search should be made, and these tokens found about vs, we are all dead men: there's not so much mercie in Gripe, as in the Plague.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Agreed. Widdow, we haue some money to pay to a Londoner in Bedford here; and he's not yet come to receiue it. Will you locke it vp safe for vs?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But heare you? Deliuer it not to any one of vs. Except all three demand it to gether, keepe it still.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Helpe her to beare it in, and see't layd vp.
Zlid, my wife takes degrees; she rises fairely.
I sold her hither whore some trickes to do.
Now she's turn'd whore, and Bawd, and Hostice too.
Stand close deare wits, and shadow me disguise.
She cast me downe, and by her fall Ile rise.
Husbands that loue your honour as your life;
Learne now to be reueng'd, on a false wife.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Your friends expect you Sir.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Sweet, I would go.
But here's a charming beauty, that sayes no.
Will you walke off a little— to the meddow?
I haue a tiny businesse with you, widdow?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What is your will, Sir? I'm in haste: be short.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: The thing thou wotst on, halfe a minutes sport.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Forbeare, libidinous Groome.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Groome? I'm a man.
And can do, Hostice, what another can.
Come, shall I speake in gold, and action?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Be damn'd, inchanter, with thy golden spells.
Thou thinkst, gold can buy lust, when nothing els.
Yet I do loue thy soule. Thinke, thinke, how deare,
A moments ioy is bought with endlesse feare.
How ill the flesh steales his vniust delight,
When the soule suffers an eternall night.
Flatter thy glowing hopes with heate no more.
Be not deceiu'd; thy Hostice is no whore.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: So: spoke my out-side braue; did my rich huske
Allow me impudent; and my vndown'd chinne
Promise my bloud vnsuck'd out by this sinne,
You would runne madde on me.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Sooth, thou much errest.
I neuer saw that person (except one,
Who iustly claim'd my loue, now dead and gone)
In whose embracements I would sooner locke the treasures of my heart.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Now, now, she's comming.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: If you had mou'd my eares with a chast suite, I should haue listn'd.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Braue! she's mine already.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: I cannot loue thee now.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p:
No, I cannot
conceiue a good thought of thee.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: I hate thee.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Heigh? handy, dandy, fast and loose, braue diuell.
Ile coniure you for this. Come, will you loue me?
Or no matter for your loue, will you lie with me?
Doe, or lie alone i'th meddow here. I shall leaue your tempting eyes for the Crowes to picke out.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Defend me goodnesse.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Whistle not so lowd, lest I cut your pipe, Come on.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: Honour or life, how shall I saue you both?
Sir, I shall spoyle you. I ha' bene long a sinner.
A common sinner, Sir, and am not sound.
You cannot scape infection, if you touch me.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Humh! the poxe, say you? well, you'l not reueale me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You need not, Sir, distrust my silence. Wrongs
That scape heauens hand, need not feare mortall tongs.
This world's turn'd Bedlam, rauing, desperate-badde.
It stagger'd drunke before, now it runs mad.
More customers?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: But, Sir, respect your life, your conscience.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Thou saist well, for my life. But for my conscience, Tis like a Surgions, that takes money for letting out blood. Thinke o' my morgage.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Vpon my life, he'll kill her. O presumption,
How dost thou dare heauens iustice? I must study
To interpose prevention. Sir, I'm your sonne:
This brest you gaue me, and Ile still conserue it,
A faithfull closet to locke vp your secrets.
How will you strike? Pistoll her?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: No: that speakes
Like an obstreperous Aduocate, too loud,
In th'cares of iustice. Murder, like your Iesuite,
Should whisper death in silence— sleeping silence.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I apprehend it, poyson. Sir, Ile buy you
A speedy potion.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: Not too deare, good sonne.
I would not ha't too deare: my mony's gone.
Two peny-woorth of Rats-bane, w' haue experience,
W'll do't; do't throughly.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Ile prouide it, Sir.
Ile be your Apothecarie; but by no meanes
Minister it my selfe. You must do that, Sir:
I cannot doe you better seruice. Rare!
Then bring my father to the Galhouse.
Be petulant, and let your wanton mirth,
Giue you forgetfull of all wrong.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Come widow, I forgiue thee now: I hope thou't forgiue me too. I'm come to drinke downe all malice.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Pray' Sir, lead the way. Ile follow.
Looke vp, deare friend: what thus deiects you?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Wonders, miracles— I must needs poyson thee.
Be not dismay'd, my poyson shall not hurt thee:
Ile tell thee all

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: Hostice, Pray 'helpe me to the money quickly. I must pay't instantly.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: You shall Sir.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: So, if my new-borne plots hold constant life,
Ile cheate my theeues, but aboue all, my wife.
Thanke you, good Widow. Youth, tel the
Gentlemen I'm gone to tender the money. Bid
sp.p: 'hem be merry and continue their healths. Ile take my round, when I come againe. Farewell Ostice.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Y'are welcome Sir,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Gone, sayst thou? and with the mony? fire and gunpowder! how are we blowne vp?

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Prettie handsome!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ostice—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Good leach, stand further off: your breath's too violent▪

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Did we not charge you not to deliuer the money, but to vs all three together?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Masse, tis true. How forgetfully are we cheated?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are a coozening woman.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You doe lye!

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Keepe the peace. Ostice, you'l make it good to vs, three hundred pound, a pretty competent summe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Furies and Fiends! wits, you do fairly striue.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: I thought this faiery mony would nere thriue.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I haue heard all this roguerie.
Cheare, Widow: let not sorrow make thee sicke.
Perhaps, Ile catch the knaues at their owne tricke.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p:
So ho-my master's turn'd Reueller. I neuer lost my name
since I came into his staruice, till now. Vck! a miracle, I am not Thirsty.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Now my wise kindred, why looke you so pale?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O, Ile put off my wedding. I will not for all Bedford marry to morrow.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: No? why?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O, my Vncle reaching for a Cup, ouerthrew the salt towards me— towards me. O tis ominous.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: The falling of a salt keep thee from mariage! well, I haue a strange medicine, of quick cure to this conceited sicknesse. Robin, fetch me some wine. Coz, how dost feele thy selfe?

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Hee shakes as if he had the burning agew.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Perplexed Cousin, perplexed. I had rather a good Lordship had falne toward me.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Tut man, salt seasons all things; fish or flesh.
And troth, thou need'st it: for thy witte's but fresh.
Here bloud, I drinke to thee.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Now could I dance like a Dutch Froe: my heeles are as light as my head.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh I recant. Cousin, I will marry.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: What meant you Sir, to spill the wine vpon him?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: 'Twas a mischance Sir.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.l: No: it was good hap.
Tis a good signe, t' haue wine spilt in ones lappe:
This makes amends for the salt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: I thought this docke would fetch your nettle out.
I see. small wind turnes a fooles mill about. Let's goe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yonder comes my Physician and his potion.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: I haue here two papers: one of sugar, and that's for my selfe: another of poyson, and that's for my Ostice. Let me be right-right. I should make faire worke, if I were mistaken now. Ha widow! th' art a Churle a— very churle, that wouldst not keepe companie with thy guests. I ha' brought thee a cup of wine here: health and bloud to thee, sweete Widow.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: A miracle: An Vsurer drunke at's owne cost.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: There's a whole cup for thee: pledge mee chucke. Nay tarry, tarry: thou must haue sugar to 't; women loue sweet things, I know. So, off with't bottome and all: the deeper the sweeter. Ha Ostice, my sonne shall giue thee a lease of thine Inne.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I would hee could grant me a lease of my life: for I grow sick sir. Robin, looke in.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: (Excellent rattes-bane) it workes already. Widow, dost remember since thou wast in my studie? and y faith what foundst there?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Nothing, but what I left behinde me, Sir. I'm very sicke.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: (Ile nere trust poyson els.) This cottons wel yet. No sooner dead, but my sonne shall ceaze on all the goods. Search the coffers for my morgage. If it be lost, yet now shee I keepe counsell.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: This wine hath made me thirsty: I'm not well.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Hye thee to bedde and sweat. A little posset with two-penny worth of horse-spice. O tis excellent to put one into a sweat. Farewell widow.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: So I'm recouerd now: thy absence cures me.
O earth! thou center of the world and sinne;
Tsty Paradise is lost t'th'art only now
A larger stable, where all vices dwell.
Did not the Sunne shine, I should thinke thee hell.
sp.p: Lucky! here comes the cheater. Sir, the money is askt for by the Gentlemen, your friends: They threaten to arrest me, but I hope sir, you'l be my quittance.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Yes: on this condition.
Let me enioy thy loue on this soft ground:
Ile pay it backe, were it three hundred pound.
Stirre not: this chargeth you: are you not content?
Come, with a silent kisse seale your consent.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sir, you know my disease. I'm dangerous.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p:
The poxe? O I haue knowne London too long to bee
afraid of the poxe. Come, will you vnlocke? I ha' the golden key. If not, Ile to Virginia, like some cheating Bankrout, and leaue my Creditour ith' suddes. You know the Iayle. Ha you neuer bin hir'd to yawle for the whole prison? and whule to the passengers?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Sorcerer, thy circle cannot hold me.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: No, I would haue yours holde mee. Come, will you fadge?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Not, if thou killst me: not if thy murderous hand
Could put me to a death▪ (like Iesuites poison)
Ten yeeres a dying.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: No? you will repent.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: So wilt thou neuer: take my carcase, slaue:
Whiles there's a soule within; no lustfull hand
Did or shall euer touch it.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Politick whore!
What do you ken me now?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: My husband? ô,
Into your armes I flie.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Infection, no.
Yare dangerous by your owne confession.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Alas! I forg'd that answere, to auoid
Sinfull embracings. Brothels sicke indeed
Of that contagion, sooth and smother't vp,
To tempt distrustfull commers on, at once
To their owne profit, and the others ruine.
They speake false, to do false the safer. I
To saue my conscience did my flesh bely.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: You cannot tempt me Siren; I am resolute.
Thou art a cunning Bitch, and I am proud
Of such expected meanes to my reuenge.
Harke, how Ile quittance thy abhorred lusts.
First, thou shalt be arrested for the money,
Whereof I cheated thee: so be restrain'd
From thy old straggling, mew'd vp like a haggard;
Till the Assise comes, then thou shalt be hang'd.
I heare thou standst bound ouer for suspicion
Of robbing Gripe. I did the villanie.
Ile ha't prou'd thine: so thou shalt hang for me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Deare husband, do so.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Husband me no more:
That name was cancell'd when you first playd whore.
Now garden-pot, you water your sad feares,
But I am no loue-foole, wonne with womans teares.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O prosecute your wil. Thus on my knees,
And with a heart more humbled, I intreat,
And I must haue it granted ere I rise;
Be pleas'd to make this life a sacrifice,
To expiate your wrath. I freely yeeld it,
For your redemption. For your hate I dye;
That might not liue in your loues companie.
If I confesse not guilty, to saue you,
Imagine then all your suspicions true.
But when for your debts I haue payd this life,
Beleeue but then, you had a faithfull wife.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: O, thou wouldst melt a rocke. My heart's too dead,
To sprout at this wet Aprill. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Peace and content attend you: and let still
Mercie forgiue, and rectifie your ill.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: What? not dead yet? but weeping? come, come dry
Vp all thy teares: goe hye thee in, and dye.
Much villanie is now together pack't.
The Scene growes full. Your patience this last act.

div.head: Act. Quint.
div.stage: Enter old Brace, the true Abbot. Abbot.
div.l: TO man, how sweet is breath! yet sweetest of all,
That breath, which from his natiue ayre doth fall.
How many weary pases haue I measur'd!
How many knowne and vnknowne dangers past,
Since I commenc'd my tedious Pilgrimage,
The last great worke of my death-yeelding age!
Yet am I blest, that my returning bones
Shall be rak't vp in Englands peacefull earth.
Oh happy Englishmen, if your sore eyes
Did not looke squint on your felicities!
How other Countries enuy, what you loth,
And surfet on: and would make that their pride,
Which is by your contempt still vilefied!
This sicknesse fulnesse breedes in most mens blood;
None lesse, then the possessors, know what's good.
Now to my deputy: here his glories end.
But stay: he comes to meet me. Ile attend.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Confound this damn'd foxe: he has cheated mee of the best prey, I euer shark'd for. Would I could light on him; I haue a Constable here should make him stand.

sp.speaker: Brac.
sp.l: What's this? sharking, foxing, and a pistoll?
Th'embleme of theefe, cheater, murderer?
Sure, this vile Elderne was not of my planting.
I know him: Tis his brother, to whose trust I did infeoffe my place.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: I was directed this way to the Abbot.
My lord— the Iudge detain'd by sicknesse from to morrow's Session, desires your lordships ayde to the supply of his owne place. Th' assistant Iustices rest their determining sentence on your lippes.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.p: Ile giue my old attendance.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Your lordships leaue.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I leaue your lordship too.
I must about this mischiefe to preuent:
Ile force you both your offices repent.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.p: So, so, so. My customers drop in roundly. Welcome, Mr. Gripe, and the rest of my good friends, welcome! I am very glad to see you here. My house was not grac'd with an Vsurer, and vnder-Sheriffe, many a day before; though I ha' been pester'd with abundance of honester fellowes. Speake, shal's be merry? what will you haue to dinner?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: A rope. What dost thou tell me of dinner?

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.p: No Sir, that shall be kept for your supper.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Giue me so me Sacke and Aqua vitae. I wil be drunk presently.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: It's cleere. I haue twenty cases for't.
The concealing of murder is but man-slaughter. I must ha' my booke.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Giue 's some Sacke, I say: mun tut, &c.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: My Vncle committed? Iustice it selfe sent to the Iayle?

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Cousin, sweet Cousin, runne, scudde, fly— to Sir Bare Notwithstanding: he lyes but three miles off; he's in my debt: bid him release me, and Ile release him.

sp.speaker: Griff.
sp.p: Stay Sir. He's in my debt too: I ha' solicited for Sir Bare these seuen yeeres, and haue nothing but bare thankes.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Nay then, take me with you. Thus—
sp.stage: Enter Beniamin, Robin, Thirsty; Thirsty climbing vp into a tree. Rob. into a bush.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Ha you your lesson perfect?

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Yes, yes: as a Mid-wife her errand to a Citizens wife. There's not an Owle in an Iuy-bush, nor a Parrat at a Drugsters dore, has whoo whoop, or walke Knaue, more perfit.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Robin, do't cunningly. My Dad shall be
Only to me beholding for his life.
By that aduantage I recall his loue.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Cousin, fly euery step. Remember, like a Iury-man, you goe vpon life and death.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Happinesse grant, that no Hare crosse him ith' way: his superstitious legges will retire, though wee hang for't. Come, shall we keep the rule of the place, and drinke drunke now?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Now kindred, whither trot you so fast?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh Cousin, about a deede of charitie; to saue your father, and two or three knaues more from hanging. I am going to Sir Bare Notwithstanding; to saue them out of prison: they haue sau'd him often.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Sir Bare Notwithstanding, he's a great man, Cousin.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Hee had three Lordships fell to him at a clappe; the worst worth 400. a yeere.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Yet hee's bare notwithstanding.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Hee has sold his Caroch with foure Flanders mares, because he would retire himselfe and liue ith' Country.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Yet he's Bare Notwithstanding. But to himselfe Cousin, farewell.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: To him, quoth he? I will to him, were the diuell in my way.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Porke, porke.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: The diuell porke you. What dismall bird crokes disaster to my iourney!

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Porke.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay, if the destinies haue set the Rauen against mee, Ile returne sure— yet let me see. So my Vncle may bee hang'd, Ile on, come what will.

sp.speaker: Thir.
sp.p: Porke.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: O this blacke bird tolles like a passing-bell,
My owne sad mischiefe and my Vncles knell.
Yet why am I so timorous; when charitie
Bids me go on, shall a Rauen hinder me?
Ile keep aloose and passe— oh a spirit, a spirit.
The Widdowes Ghost. Bromley, Lawyer, Vncle, hang.
Take all your fortunes, I'le no further gang.
It's an vnhallow'd place, a dismall day.
Betide what will, Il'e backe againe some way.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Come downe, Rauen.

sp.speaker: Thirst.
sp.p: Come out, Spirit.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Blind, credulous foole! He that shall trust at need
Such nice and tottring cockscombes, shall thus speed.
Should his sicke father send him for some drugges,
Hee would turne backe at such imagin'd bugges.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Come, mother, friend, and wife; take these back places,
Where you may heare vnseene: that when time serues,
I may produce you. Works and houres are spent
Then well, when we doe good, or ill preuent.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.l: I cannot iudge, what is this dayes successe.
All-ruling powers the doubtfull sequele blesse.
sp.stage: Enter Curfew with other assistants, Vaster in a Priests habit, Valentine like a Physician, the Iaylor with Gripe, Bromley, Griffin, &c.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: My Lord, whose place I personate, being sicke,
Hath thus design'd mee, both to heare and censure
The criminall causes, which offend the peace
Of our dread Soueraigne, and his subiects weale.
Whiles we launce Vlcers, we the body heale.
The charge I giue in short, you of the Iury,
Looke to your Oath and conscience: let not fauour
Shut vp your eyes, nor malice open them
Too wide. You vnderstand, our lawes are good.
Tis pitie that they should be writ in blood.
But since conniuence at vnlawfull deeds
Giues but encouragement, and wee cannot strike
With sword of Iustice the deseruing faults,
Except you giue the persons to our hands:
All on your vigilant information stands.
Proceede to the Inditements.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: We are all cast away. Sir Bare is not come.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Pull downe that counterfeit, proud, arrogant, puffe:
Could your intrusion not content it selfe
T'vsurpe my office, but you must abuse
The Kings deputed Iudge?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Downe with him, downe with him.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: Iaylor, receiue him to your custodie,
Till our iust censure giue him punishment.
Foxe, I shall hunt you out.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: Do't with a poxe.
The goose sometimes must sit and iudge the Fox.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: Proceed; the day hastens.

sp.speaker: Clark.
sp.p: Marian Sorrow widow, yeeld thy body, and saue thy baile.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Sir, shee is dead: her felonie is answer'd Before a higher Court.

sp.speaker: Clarke.
sp.p: That is the woman that Gripe is suspected to haue poyson'd. Godfrey Gripe stand to the Barre. You are indited for the murther of Marian Sorrow widdow: guilty or not?

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Not guilty, my Lord: let all the world testifie of my honest carriage. I haue liued all my dayes in good name and fame.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: Stand not vpon your credit and good deeds.
Your haruest would be small, if like your seeds.
If all that know thee stood about this place,
And had free liberty to speake their thoughts,
Round ecchoing curses would amaze thy soule,
And with hells damned crue thy name enroule.
But when the Widdow, Orphane call for plagues
On thy blacke life, thou hy'st vnto thy bagges;
There dost applaud and hugge thy wretched selfe:
As solace 'gainst all woes lay in thy pelfe.
Thou hast no god but gold: that Deitie
Thou shouldst adore, and would still succour thee,
Is quite reiected. And that Idol, money,
Which beares away thy confidence and heart,
When thou art plagued, aggrauates thy smart.
Thou art the Deuils Executioner.
His rankest plague on earth's an Vsurer.
Spirits in hell whip soules: extorting slaues
Torment poore bodies so before their graues.
Thou art a gulfe, poore mens estates to drinke.
A quagmire; none passe ore thee, but they sinke.
Vnlesse Strepsiades-like, men could deuise
To plucke the Moone by Sorcerie from the skies;
Thy moneth and gaine will come. Like some at sea,
(Yet dangerlesse of shipwracke more then they)
Thou slumbrest in a base lethargicke swoone.
Let others toyle, thy iournye's done as soone.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Will not this moue him?

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: Nature in all inferiour things hath set
A pitch or terme, when they no more shall get
Increase and off-spring. Vnrepayred houses
Fall to decay: old Cattell cease to breed.
And sappelesse trees deny more fruite or seed.
The earth would hart-lesse and infertile be,
If it should neuer haue a Iubile.
Only the Vsurers money genders still:
The longer, lustier: Age this doth not kill.
He liues to see his moneys moneys money,
Euen to a hundred generations reach.
He, whiles his interest money in do's troule,
Cares not to lose the principall, his Soule.
He like a cleanly Alchymist can soke
And draw much siluer, yet waste none in smoke.
Thou lendst, like water powr'd on sea-cole fire,
Or on a lode of Lime a showre of rayne.
sp.p: It seemes to coole heate, but doth more enflame.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: His conscience has deafe eares.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: When all is done,
And thou hast swel'd thy heapes; to say no more,
Thy coffer's onely rich, and thou art poore.
This common plague is on all Vsurers showne:
Th'haue much, yet are not masters of their owne.
One day thy stintlesse mind shall haue enough;
When the diuided peeces of thy selfe
Shall in their seuerall doomed mansions dwell:
Enough of mould in graue, of fire in hell.
But I spend breath in vaine; come, let's proceed.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: No further. You haue made my conscience bleed.
I heere confesse my selfe guilty of all,
Euen of this murder too.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.p: Let mercie fall on thy distressed soule. Now to the rest.

sp.speaker: Clark.
sp.p: Nicholas Bromley, you are indited for the murther of William Sager, &c. Guilty or not?

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: Not guilty? Who testifies against me!

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: In case of Murder should we neuer iudge
By circumstanciall likelihoods and presumptions,
No life could be secure.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Puffe! shift for your selues; Sir Bare Notwithstanding dares not be seene.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.l: O, I am lost.
My Lord, I'm guilty: so is Griffin too:
He did conceale the fact, that I did doe,
We shar'd the Lands together.

sp.speaker: Abbot.
sp.l: Powerfull truth!
Murder will out, though by the Actors mouth.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: O Beniamin, I haue vndone
My life, my state, my credite, and my Sonne.
But I'm resolu'd to dye, so Monarchs must:
Rich men as well as poore, must turne to dust.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Me thinkes I could preuent all this.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: Alas, thou lov'st me; but tis not possible.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Sir, I haue here a booke already drawne,
Seale to it freely, and Ile saue your life.
You shall confirme me your vndoubted heire,
And then surrender Vasters morgag'd lands.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Tis done.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: My Lord and all this bench be witnesse to it.
Then thus I quit you, widdow, appeare in Court.
In earnest, see, she liues, that dy'd in sport.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir, thanke your Drugster, else I had dy'd by you.
And you for me receiu'd a murderers due.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: So, I am cousen'd finely, finely—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My Lord, I challenge this widdow for cheating me of 300. pounds. This is one of her old trickes.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My Lord, my selfe and two intrusted friends
Came hither to pay money on a bond,
Whiles the receiuer did deferre his comming;
We gaue this coozening woman, being Hostice,
The whole summe to lay vp: and straightly charg'd her,
Not to deliver't, but to vs all together.
She sayes one of vs three demanded it
Of her in haste, and ranne away: and thus
We lost our money, and the bond lies forfeit.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Your Lordships leaue. Tis true, she not denies,
But they so charg'd her, and she was so coozend.
Therefore she yeelds to paiment. Let 'hem come
All three together, they shall haue the money.

sp.speaker: Grif.
sp.p: Vpon my faith, a prettie quillet.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: Wittie and iust. How say you? heere produce
The other two, your satisfaction's ready.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: The widdow's cleard: but master Valentine—
Nay, man, come neerer, you'd haue present pay.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, Sir, let it euen goe.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: So must not you.
You gaue 300. pound to her: tis true.
Which like a subtle Quacksaluer, you robd
My father of; Sprites, Fairies—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am cob'd.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: It's true, my lord: this is one of the Fairies. Iustice, Iustice.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well, if there be no remedie, I hope,
I shall not dance alone vpon the rope.
My lord, here's the other Fairie.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: O Sir, haue I found you?
Pull off that borrowd habite from his backe.
O that such foule deeds should be hid in blacke.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.l: My Lord, this Widow's accessary too:
She plotted, she receiu'd. Iustice, iustice.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: But late thy song was mercy, now all iustice?
Here's all the goodnes of an Vsurer.
She sau'd his life, he would now hang her.

sp.speaker: Gripe.
sp.p: She has robb'd me, vndone me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It is most true, my lord, she plotted all.

sp.speaker: Curf.
sp.l: (Your villanie, Ostice, we shall now retort.
You cheated vs, and we will hang you for't.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: How doe these mischiefes grow, like Hidra's heads, faster by cutting off!

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Prodigious villaines! will they thus cast away an innocent woman?
Yet I most vile of all, that thus stand by,
And for my fault behold my poore wife dye.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: My lord, vpon my soule this woman's cleare:
And only malice thus accuseth her.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Speake, woman, art thou guilty?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: My lord, I begge a word with my Confessor,
Then I shall answere. Sir, a word in priuate.
Now Vaster, ope thy vnbeleeuing eyes:
Lo, thy deuoted wife for thy sinne dyes.
Yeeld but this kindnesse to my latest breath,
Thou hate'st me liuing, loue me yet in death.
Farewell— My lord, I will not say, I'm guilty;
Do as your euidence and wisedome leades you.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: This knot is hard to vndo.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: My lord, Ile help you.
Loe, I am that third Fairy, that pronounce
This woman cleare, and those two periur'd knaues.
We three are guilty: let your sentence come.
I haue deseru'd, will not despaire my doome.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: My lord, he sayes not true: hee's innocent: I guilty.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Speake on your soules, which of these tongues speak truth.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Curf. My lord, the woman's cleare.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Pernicious Villaines, hopelesse to be good:
That thus haue stroue to spill the guiltlesse bloud.
Widow, y'are quitted. Sir, waite you your doome.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.p: With patience. Beniamin Gripe, I here accuse you for murdering Richard Vaster.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: My lord, I found that Vaster dying, bury'd him,
Saw him receiuing death by this mans sword.
Theft's a great sin, but murder most abhorr'd.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.p: Speake; is this possible?

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: We met in single combate in the field:
It seemes his life vnto my sword did yeeld.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Ay me, my father slaine?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: And by his friend?
Fate, whither will thy proiects tend!

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: My husbands hand my fathers life vndoes:
For this fact he must dye: thus both I lose.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Forgiue me all, by me you all haue lost,
The wife a Husband, children a deare Parent:
Thus I returne you all some recompence.
Nan thou shalt lose a husband.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Heauens defend.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Mother, you lose a son, brother a friend.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Can nature so degenerate, that a man should liue, stand by, and see another suffer for murdering him?

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Once againe off disguise.
My lord, thus I preuent this fear'd disaster
My second case pull'd off, I am plaine Vaster.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: My father?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: My deare husband.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Most, most deare friend.
My loue to you doth beyond bounds extend.
My Lord, first to this honourable Bench,
I' here present the Kings most gracious pardon
For vs three here: heauen no lesse pardon vs.
Now to my wife: see wench, I am new borne;
Rench'd from the plague of a suspected horne.
Blacke Iaundeys of the minde, thou fained spirit,
That haunts mens quiet thoughts with troubling shades.
Pernicious Ielousie, that like needlesse Physicke
Divertest health to voluntary sicknesse,
I brush thee off like dust. See, I am now
New marry'd to my loue and to my life.
Neuer could man boast a more constant wife.
Deare Beniamin, now Sonne, what I haue left
Of all my shipwrack'd fortunes, shall be thine.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.p: Resume your former state, my father yeelds it.

sp.speaker: Vast.
sp.l: Thankes to your honestie, not his; yet thus,
Some meanes of satisfaction I haue found;
Ile pay him backe his lost three hundred pound:
The fairie money, which was iust the price
Of my redeemed lands.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: Now master Bromley,
That vniuersall mercie to our guilt,
May be affoorded, and no blood be spilt:
Surrender vp your lease for the three liues
To Sagers wife and children, and Ile quit you.

sp.speaker: Brom.
sp.p: I do most freely yeeld it.

sp.speaker: Sag.
sp.l: Sager liues,
And hartie thankes for your forc'd kindnesse giues.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: Happy delusions! in such waies of ill,
I wish men may be thus mistaken still.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Rauens, and Sprites, and Fairies, and Hares and diuels-Thus haue I lost my wench, lost my money, lost my watch, lost my wits. I doe here renounce the faith of all Almanackes, Physiogmoners, Palmists, Fortune-tellers. Erra Pater was an Asse, and so are Prognosticators, his children, from generation to generation.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.l: I haue drunke powerfull physicke, and the Dropsie
Of my (till now) nere quenched auarice,
Dries vp like dew at the ascending Sunne.
Vaster, take back your lands; and for the money,
Giue it my sonne in portion with your daughter.
Hencefoorth Ile study to requite the wrongs,
Which I haue done poore men by vsurie,
And vomit vp th'extortions, that doe lie
As vndigested crudities on my conscience.
My future life shall bee in mercie spent.
I'm Gripe no more; that name I doe repent.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: All Chronicles be fill'd with this; and let it
Be as a wonder to all eares imparted.
England had once an Vsurer conuerted.

sp.speaker: Ben.
sp.l: THe Session now dissolues: each Iustice rises:
No hurt is done; this is the milde Assises.
We haue scap'd faire thus farre: yet there remaines
A stronger iudgement to passe on our paines.
Too much to hope or doubt we must not dare.
We humbly then stand at your censures barre.
If the worst comes that may be, yet I looke
For this grace, to be saued by my booke.
But if with your applause our merit stands:
Faith then be friends with vs, and giue's your hands.
